reviewText:
Download size: about 15 gigabytes
Play time: about 5 hours to go through the campaign on normal mode. You can spend a lot more on multiplayer though.
Controller recommended

Injustice: Gods Among Us had a free weekend recently and I decided to give it a try, maybe rake in some easy achievements since it’s supposed to be a pretty short game campaign wise.  I managed to beat the game on normal mode in a little over 5 hours but didn’t really try any multiplayer because my internet was acting up. Since Injustice is a fighting game I originally thought the “story mode” would be like Street Fighter or Mortal Kombat where everything is really just character backstory with a general tournament plotline.  Instead, it’s more like a 5 hour movie where you take control during the fight scenes.

Spoilers:
In an alternate universe, the Joker somehow tricked Superman into killing his family and destroying Metropolis. In a rage, Superman kills the Joker and seizes control, creating the One World government where he and a bunch of other heroes rule with an iron fist to make sure something like that never happens again. Anyone who disagrees with him is killed, even some of his friends in the Justice League. Most of them join up with him though, including a few villains. Batman (who is still good) uses a dimensional transporter to pull in a bunch of heroes from “our” universe in an attempt to stop Evil Superman. By the way, Evil Superman has used Kryptonian technology to create a pill that makes his teammates stronger and tougher (and Batman has stolen some of them). It’s the game’s way of evening the odds so super powered characters like Superman or Doomsday don’t squash regular humans like Batman or Green Arrow in one punch.  Unlike other fighting games, you don’t choose one person to play through the story. In the campaign you start off as Batman and as the story goes along you switch between people like Flash, Aquaman, Green Arrow, Green Lantern, and Wonder Woman. You also play as a few villains who opposed Evil Superman and are now counted as “good guys” during the campaign. As I mentioned earlier, the game is telling a story, and you only take control during the fight scenes.

Despite its high graphics and environmental interactions (like throwing background objects at your enemy) Injustice is still a 2D fighting game like Mortal Kombat or Street Fighter. Each character has a bunch of special moves and a “super bar” (I forgot what the actual name is). You charge your super bar by using special moves or by taking damage. You can use sections of the super bar to give additional power to your special moves, or do special things like push your enemy away when the enemy has you in a combo (obviously this is a great tool for pros). Since I’m a newb I only used it for the character specific super moves. These can only be used when the super bar is completely full and can deal massive damage to the enemy if they don’t block (If they block the first hit, the super move kind of fizzles out). All the super moves are cinematic attacks like Final Fantasy moves where your character smashes the enemy around showcasing the characters super power (or technology). And during the fight don’t forget to exploit environmental hazards. Doing things like triggering a background missile launcher or picking up and throwing a car can do a lot of damage, and is unblockable. Most stages also have a couple of “transitions” where you can knock your enemy through the wall at the edge and follow him through to a new area (does a lot of damage too).

I used an Xbox 360 controller to play and I would definitely advise against playing with just a keyboard. The special moves might be easier with a keyboard, but you’d have a lot of trouble actually fighting. Since I’m inexperienced with game controllers, I had trouble doing special moves that require reversing directions. For example, Batman’s batarang attack is Back->Forward + Medium attack. Whenever I tried, it would just do a regular punch, and it was the same with every other special move that requires reverse directions. I’m sure there’s just something I’m missing though. The game has combos as you’d expect in a modern fighting game and I didn’t realize until later that you’re supposed to press the buttons fast, not wait for a hit to connect before starting the next attack. This means that by the time your character has thrown the first punch, you should have already punched in all the buttons to the combo, unless you’re trying to juggle the enemy (keep hitting them while they’re in the air and can’t react). I haven’t played many modern fighting games so I don’t know if this is commonplace.

Pros:
+Excellent graphics and story. I especially liked trying out the supermoves of all the characters. If the game had fatalities like Mortal Kombat, I probably would have spent the whole weekend trying them all out.
+A lot of variety in the game, from environmental hazards, to character special attacks, to the 29 different playable characters. During the campaign it actually seemed pretty easy most of the time. I didn’t lose a round until I met Catwoman, who kicked my ♥♥♥.

Cons:
-A lot of the Steam achievements for Injustice are basically impossible unless the opponent is cooperating (or it’s just you with 2 controllers). For example, using every environmental interaction in one fight, or winning a fight using only one kind of attack. Also, a lot of the achievements are grinds. For example, using every single super move of every character or do 10 hit combos with every character in the game. I got all the “easy” achievements, which was about 50%.
-The game download is huge. I probably spent twice as long downloading as I did playing. I backed the game files up though, so I’ll have the game available if there’s another free weekend. The system requirements aren’t that bad, I could run it smoothly with my AMD 555 processor and Radeon 7850 video card (for reference, I run Watch Dogs at 10 fps – unplayable). I was worried in the beginning because when I first ran Injustice I got about 20 frames per second. I guess it was just “settling in” though, because after a few minutes I got a steady 60 fps.

Overall Injustice is a fantastic game, though I don’t play many fighting games so I don’t have anything modern to compare it to. It’s one of those games where I would go back and play (multiplayer) if I had a half hour or so to kill. I’m sure everyone online would destroy me pretty easily though.

reviewText:
From the makers of Mortal Kombat (Ed Boon), Injustice: Gods Among Us Ultimate Edition, is an eye candy and it’s full of fan service.
Injustice is one of the best pc fighting games out there right now, it has outstanding graphics and dark art, there are 29 characters to pick from, good and bad guys (most of them have several costumes to pick from) packed with a bunch of nifty moves. The stages are iconic, interactive, and destructible, which is cool too.
The Story is short, but good (loved the parallel universes thing). Gameplay-wise the game is not too intuitive, but after a few matches you will start to get the hang of it and it’s spectacular and fun to play (some special moves are really awesome and go well with each hero or villain).
Besides story and versus modes, there are other modes and challenges to pick from and lots of extra stuff to unlock.
The music and sound are epic and so are the voices and characterization (loved the Joker).
In summary, this is a great game that is worth your money and if you like fighting games and Mortal Kombat, you shouldn't pass on this one.

De los creadores de Mortal Kombat (Ed Boon), Injustice: Gods Among Us Ultimate Edition, es un dulce para tus ojos y está lleno de fanservice.
Injustice es uno de los mejores juegos de pelea para Pc que hay actualmente, tiene unas gráficas sobresalientes y un arte oscuro, cuenta con 29 personajes para escoger, buenos y malos (la mayoría de ellos con varios disfraces a elegir), y todos cuentan con bastantes movimientos bien elaborados. Los escenarios son icónicos, interactivos y destructibles, lo cual es genial.
La historia es un poco corta, pero buena (me encanto lo de los universos paralelos). Con respecto a la jugabilidad, el juego no es muy intuitivo, pero después de algunas batallas comenzarás a entenderlo y es espectacular y divertido (algunos movimientos especiales son de verdad increíbles y van bien con cada héroe y villano).
Además de los modos de vs y de la historia, hay otros modos y desafíos y muchas cosas extra para desbloquear.
La música y los sonidos son épicos y también lo son las voces y la caracterización (me encantó el Joker).
En Resumen, este es un gran juego que vale tu dinero y si te gustan los juegos de pelea y Mortal Kombat, no deberías dejarlo pasar.

reviewText:
Let me preface this review by stating a few facts:

1) I'm not a fan of fighting games.
2) I'm not a big comic fan, though I enjoy the Marvel movies (not the DC movies).
3) I rarely play a game to the end.

That being said, here is my opinion of Injustice:

Single player campaign:
I started playing at about 2AM thinking I would just check it out before bed. It is now 7:30 AM and I just finished the single player campaign and a few of the S.T.A.R. Labs. I lost 8 matches and made one run to the store, so I got nearly 5 hours out of the campaign. That's not bad considering I only paid about 8 dollars on amazon. Luckily I didn't buy it for the multiplayer (well, sort of), more on that in a bit.
As soon as the game started, I was hooked. The transitions between the story sequences and the fights were spot on. You smoothly flow into a fight and it does not break the immersion. The action in the cuts scenes will be amazing for any comic/action/superhero fan. The graphics are great and match the cut scenes and the only loading scenes I can recall are after I lost a battle, and those were very short. There may have been more, but I was so sucked into the game I did not notice them. After you complete the game, there are other modes you can play to unlock a plethora of costumes, concept art, backgrounds, music, and other neat stuff.

Controls: If you have ever played Mortal Kombat you will be pretty comfortable with the controls. The combos are not as extensive (at least none that I could pull off). I used a wireless xbox controller, and as happens with a lot of games, the analog stick does not have adjustable or proper deadzones. This meant I was relegated to the D-pad as my analog has a tendency to stick in the upwards position (on all four of my controllers). This doesn't happen on my xbox, only the PC. Sometimes it felt a little cluncky or unresponsive pulling off special moves and semed to execute a move I had not intended.

I played the game on the default difficulty, but noticed something odd. If you lose a fight, the game seems to lower the difficulty. While fighting one particular character, I lost twice in a row. The first time I had my ♥♥♥ handed to me, the second time was nearly even, but the third time...the third time I could stand next to him and he would do the same. He became dissapointingly easy. This happened on more than one occasion. Whith each failure, I found myself facing a weaker AI. To me, that was very dissapointing as I felt I was not being challenged. You may want to play the game on a harder difficulty if you want a challenge. It's been years since I played a fighter, yet I pretty much blazed though most of the enemies. Even later in the game I was able to beat a few without taking damage.

Multiplayer:  Is non-existant. I attempted multiple times to jump into a random match in each mode and never had any luck. So I joined a lobby looking to challenge someone only to find 1 person in the lobby, and they were unresponsive. As I said earlier, I didn't exactly buy it for the multiplayer, I bought a copy for me an a friend so he could fulfill his fantasy of of being Wonder Woman while get getting spanked by me playing Superman, so I'm not terribly dissapointed by the lack of any community in MP. If you don't have people to play with, and are looking to fight random nerds on the interwebs, you may want to look elsewhere. Luckily the single player mode was insanely fulfilling. Only twice before have I spent hours in front of my computer beating a game to it's end.

Summary: Awesome single-player campaign that is well worth the money if bought on sale (it's $7.50 on Amazon right now, get it). Non-existant MP may turn some players away.

reviewText:
If you've ever played Mortal Kombat , picking up Injustice: Gods Among Us will feel like putting on a warm, well-worn pair of slippers. Well, if slippers could make you capable of supernatural speed and strength as well as giving you the power to shoot lasers out of your eyes, that is.

The resemblance is no surprise: developer NetherRealm Studios has worked on Mortal Kombat for years. And everything that's good about Mortal Kombat - including the huge, cinematic moments, the boatload of extra features and unlockables, and a surprisingly robust story - is its doing.

Injustice is based on a group of characters from the DC Comics universe, including everyone's favourite superhero, Batman. All the rest of the big guns are here, too - Superman, Wonder Woman, Flash, Green Lantern. There's also a well-rounded line-up of DC villains, from the Joker (who is disappointingly not voiced by Mark Hamill) to lesser-known characters such as Killer Frost and Black Adam.

It's great to play a fighting game with a story, and in this case it's one that's true to the characters and the universe comic fans know and love. But because there are so many duplicate characters, the story can at times be a bit confusing. In comic form, stories like this work because people have time to process the differences - you can look at a panel and figure out whether that's 'regular' Batman or 'alternate universe' Batman. Some of the characters' costumes are changed enough in the game that the difference is unmistakable, but others take more time to spot.

Injustice’s main point of interest and distinction is tying in the background to gameplay and providing reasons why you’d want to pick between one location over another. You’re able to interact with objects in the environment, meaning that you can kick someone into the Batcomputer or open up a water valve into their face. Along with this you can perform an attack that transitions from one scene to another. There’s a unique cutscene for doing this in every level. Some involve characters being crushed by harrier jets, others throw inmates from Arkham Asylum on them. The inclusion of interactive environmental content might also provide difficulty with balance as different sides of the map confer different advantages and it might be unfair in high-level competition, but they’re great to watch.

With some soft-bans on characters or dedicated work in not falling victim to cheap tricks, Injustice is a great fighting game that’s not only a lot of fun, but provides a lot of answers for problems with the genre. It’s accessible, it’s intense and it’s a great spectacle.

reviewText:
“Gods Among Us: Anyone can be a Hero”
Fighting games have long since descended from their all-conquering dizzying heights (in the 80’s and 90’s) to become almost a niche genre, as both games and gamers diversify. Within this evolving landscape, ‘Injustice: Gods Among Us (The Ultimate Edition)’ manages to brawl its way into contention as a polished, well crafted fighter, that despite its issues, is a fine addition to any Fight Game enthusiast’s collection.

Campaign:  Released in late 2013, NetherRealm | Warner Bros. follow up on the commercial success of ‘Mortal Kombat: The Komplete Edition’ by essentially replicating that game within the DC Comics universe. The ‘Campaign’ mode follows the story arc from the ‘Injustice’ comic books, wherein a crazed Joker has killed Lois Lane and detonated a nuclear device in Metropolis. The game picks up with an enraged Superman asserting martial law over the planet and slowly turning from protector to oppressor. Narrated through well conceived animated cut-scenes and interspersed with 1-on-1 battles, gamers assume control of all their favorite characters as well as some others they might not have been so inclined to. The usual suspects are all here – from Batman, Superman, The Joker, Lex Luthor, Wonder Woman, Harley Quinn, Green Arrow and Bane to a host of newer faces like Doomsday, Solomon Grundy, Frost, DeathStroke and Aquaman. A variety of Single Player Arcade-style Tournaments, Challenges, and lots of unlockable comic lore round out a content-rich title.

Gameplay | Graphics | Sound:  Gameplay is fast and fluid, and the use of destructible environments and interactible objects work particularly well to convey the massive destruction wrought by epic battles between superheroes. PC controls are tight, responsive and well optimized for both M&K and Controller. Newcomers to fighting games will also relish the fact that unlike other fighters (which can be notoriously difficult to master), ‘Injustice’ utilizes a manageable 3-5 buttons for even its more complex combos making elaborate ‘Throwdowns’, ‘Special Moves’, and ‘In-Level Transitions’ executable even for non-veterans. Another positive is that all playable characters come already un-locked, eliminating the usual grind. Graphics and Sound are great overall as well.

Flaws:  In considering its flaws – Continuing issues with Multiplayer | Online Connectivity are a major concern – with poor matchmaking and worse stability making dropped connections nearly constant. Given that these same issues were identified, and displeasure loudly voiced with ‘Mortal Kombat’, the fact that they remain prevalent with the developer’s next release is almost unforgiveable. With a campaign of low replayability, limitations of other SP options and a nearly unplayable | dead Multiplayer, the overall package is dragged well down.

Overall, ‘Injustice: Gods Among Us’ is a polished modern fighting game - with a large collection of fighters (30+) to choose from, a well-crafted campaign, and satisfying fight mechanics – and is well worth your consideration particularly if you are a fan of the DC Comics Universe. A broken Multiplayer component and an overwhelming sense of déjà-vu (if you’ve also played NetherRealm’s ‘Mortal Kombat: The Komplete Edition’) blemish this otherwise ambitious fighter. Recommended (On Sale) - Rated (8.2/10)


Want More Recommendations?
Make sure to click the 'Follow' button on our Curator Page (Link Attached) to get the latest reviews updated directly onto your Activity Feed. Link:  'Game Syndicate - Curator Page'

reviewText:
This game is kind of tough for me to write a review for. On one hand, I think it's a highly enjoyable fighting game with a pretty decent story mode, a ton of options if you're into playing single player and offline with friends, but on the other hand, the online mode has been highly inconsistent in terms of stability. The game plays a lot like Mortal Kombat, but ditches the block button and 4 attack buttons in favor of 3 attacks (light,  medium, and heavy) and a power button that does different things depending on the character you choose. Another thing that helps to differentiate Injustice is that all of the fighters are separated into two tiers, which effects how they use different items in the background. A powerhouse like Bane is able to pick up cars in the background and slam them down from a decent range on opponents, whereas Nightwing will use the same vehicle either to place explosives on or flip to the other side of the screen, evading danger. It's a neat feature that somehow manages to never feel cheap and really conveys the sense of being a superhero.

Following in the footsteps of Mortal Kombat (2011), this game does include a decent story, although it is significantly shorter. The other key features of the game I feel get overlooked is the Battles mode, which is just a ladder where you fight through the AI, but includes probably about 20 variations such as classic (fighting anyone) villains only, survivor (one life bar), and combo heaven (you must land combos to damage your enemy). If these modes aren't your thing, the game also includes a mode called STAR Labs, which offers up different missions for each character that vary from just fighting.

Despite the online being kind of rough to this day, there is still a lot of fun to be had here, and it's also nice that you get all of the characters that were previously available as DLC on consoles for just the regular price of the PC version. Worth a look if you're a fan of fighting games, and I definitely think this is easier for newcomers than any Street Fighter game, but be wary if you're planning on sticking strictly to online play. It's easier if you have friends to play with that you know have good connections.

reviewText:
Injustice: Gods Among Us is a 1v1 fighting game made by NetherRealm and High Voltage Software (Mortal Kombat Komplete Edition) and published by Warner Bros. For first, beware, as its WB's tradition for ported games from consoles, even Injustice may not perform on your computer, considering possible low FPS and need to lower the details (though that's been a bigger problem at the time of the release).

Gameplay-wise it doesn't offer much new from classic scheme you may already know from other similar games (Mortal Kombat, Tekken and Street Fighter series). Combos are based on fast button mashing (specific combinations, not random) and not checking for the right moment in the character's animation. Player's speed just needs to be high, so don't expect the game letting you be lazy and mashing gamepad buttons slowly, every milisecond counts.

What stands out about the game are DC Universe characters (obviously) and the level details and variety. Levels have more floors where you can move your fight to, and you can interact with many objects in the level, as you can take them and throw at your opponent.

The game offers single-player story mode where you always fight few fights with specific character, moving on to another after. There is totally 12 chapters of the story that should provide you more than 5 hours of gameplay, depending on your set difficulty.

I haven't tried the multiplayer, but as far as the single-player content goes, the game felt mediocre and if you're not a big fan of DC Universe, you might feel similarly. For me, it ends up in just another fighting game" category. It's worth recommending but don't expect anything superior to other games in the genre.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-aW47g3sWJk

With Capcom doing their best to inundate the market with fighting games centered around the Marvel universe, the task of representing the DC universe has fallen to NetherRealm. While their first effort, Mortal Kombat Vs. DC Universe, was generally considered mediocre the quality of their Mortal Kombat reboot injected a lot of hope that their future titles would continue to be top notch. Injustice: Gods Among Us, is a strictly DC character affair that  follows in the footsteps of the MK reboot and offers an original narrative that pits heroes and villains alike in one on one beat downs. If you have always fantasized about Batman punching Aquaman in the face or Ares turning Wonder Woman into a pin cushion with a volley of arrows, this may be your best chance to bring such day dream to fruition.

Injustice: Gods Among Us offers up an original narrative that involves a parallel universe in which the Joker has tricked Superman into killing Lois Lane—an act that causes Superman to kill Joker and assume the role of a tyrant. Batman leads an insurgency against Superman's regime and, to add to the chaos, the heroes from the canon timeline cross into the Injustice universe to take up the fight against  Superfacist Superman. The tale is rather campy and thoroughly peppered with groan worthy dialogue and one liners that may induce vomiting. It does an serviceable job of bringing a mix of iconic and somewhat obscure characters together for super-sized throw downs. Comic book  fans will likely pitch a tent over the fan service and cameos while most everyone else will shrug off this delightfully absurd scenario in anticipation of the next round of fisticuffs.

While the plot in itself is not Shakespeare, the structure of the campaign mode is something that fighting game developers should take note of. Following in the footsteps of Mortal Kombat, Injustice tells it's tale by switching between characters who have some sort of objective to move the plot forward. You play a few rounds with a character as cutscenes move the events forward between fights before you are handed over to the next character who, in turn, tells their part of the tale. Quick time events also pop up on occasion and can have an impact on how much health your character and your opponent have at the onset of a match. It's a far more cohesive narrative experience than what is offered by most fighting games since you see how characters relate to one another as well as the overarching plot line. The main campaign takes about four to six hours to finish off and you will take control of about half of the 24 character roster (the ultimate edition contains 30 fighters) as part of the experience. A more traditional arcade style mode called battle mode allows you to pick a character and run through a gauntlet of opponents before seeing a character specific ending. There are also modifiers and variations of battle mode to be unlocked while playing Injustice adding masochistic options like trying to tackle the entire ladder without health regeneration between rounds.

At first, Injustice may come off as a re-skinned Mortal Kombat. Character movement and move sets are similar but God Among Us offers many new additions as well as a decent tutorial to introduce you to the mechanics. A light, medium and heavy attack are mapped to the face buttons as well as a special power button. The special power button allows the Green Arrow to fire arrows, Batman to summon mechanical bats and Superman to get a power buff. No more low punch, high punch or low kick, high kick. It must be said that many of the character's powers just don't fit the goals of the special button and thus only a few make it look like a natural addition to the game since, for many characters, the special button just triggers a power and speed buff. Blocking has been revised as well. Holding back blocks high attacks and crouching will block low attacks. Using special attacks fills up a gauge that can be used in a few ways such as enhancing special moves and of course dazzling super combos. The most unique feature however is the clash system. You basically bet your super gauge against your opponent and the highest bet wins. If you initiate a clash you can regain health by out-betting an opponent, though loosing will cost a significant chunk of health. It's a system that interrupts the flow of combat and could be used to strategically interrupt combos but often it feels like an irritation—particularly since the AI loves to use it after you have depleted your gauge to gain health back. Stages are also littered with objects to use against your foes and power attacks can be used to trigger ostentatious cinematic sequences that hurl your opponent into another part of the battlefield. This is a wonderful addition that makes stages come alive and adds some strategy in terms of where you are on the stage as well as augmenting your options for delivering skeleton shattering blows.

Not content with just a story mode and an arcade ladder, Injustice also features S.T.A.R. Labs which is a collection of challenges and mini games. Each individual challenge has three separate goals that is worth a star. More stars are required to unlock later challenges so getting as many as possible in each challenge is recommended to speed up progress. These additional objectives can become rather tedious and even frustrating, just like those in Mortal Kombat's Challenge Tower. There are a lot of challenges available and you will be busy for quite some time if you have the patience and the skill to take all of them on. Additionally there is a huge amount of content to unlock in the game's archives section. Costumes, music, concept art, and portraits for you online avatar can all be unlocked by completing various objectives and though purchase in the games archives with access cards that can be obtained through leveling.

Online mode offers up solid one on one bouts as well as King of the hill and Survival game types. King of the hill allows the winning player to continue competing against an entire lobby of people and survival is much the same only without a regenerating life bar between rounds. Lobbies offer some interaction to keep you entertained while waiting your turn. Connections are only as stable as the person you are fighting with so if you run into anyone with a third world internet connection prepare to have a bad time.

Visually, Injustice is a bit of a mixed bag. The stages are wonderfully detailed and crumble around the combatants on screen as your heroes deliver punishing blows. The characters themselves generally look good but skin textures are woefully plain, devoid of details like pours or variation in skin tone, while their costumes are richly detailed. This incongruency is a bit of a distraction, particularly during cutscenes. The cutscenes themselves can seem pretty empty at times with austere buildings and simple textures making up the environments. Some effects, like splashing water, are a bit bland and fail to enhance the cinematic vibe NetherRealm was going for in the story. Luckily most of this doesn't matter when the pugilism starts. Fights are smooth and they look pretty damn exciting. Expect people in your household to spectate should they catch you playing.

reviewText:
I want to recommend this game

But not on its fighting game merits.
Yes its a Fighting Game....like mortal kombat or street fighter.  But at its core its more one very long movie with places where you fight in between.

For me the game play was only ok.
It was typical fighting with special maneuvers.
You have the ability to do semi-stage fatalities like in the mortal kombat games....and the ability to hit the player to other areas and change your battle area.
You also have a super attack and a bunch of combo moves.
And the tutorial makes you practice the combo moves alot( i find that not much fun actually....i want to fight and have fun not just do a repetition motion to play...i ended up macroing the maneuvers using xpadder..i admit it)

what made me really like this game was the story.
Whether you are a DC fan or comic book fan or just someone who likes an interesting story...this game does not fail to deliver in that respect.

In essence you could probably skip this game and simply watch the entire set of videos on youtube.
But if you dont support this group...you may never get another interesting movie like story in the future.

That story i wont spoil what happens....but i will tell you how it starts.....

It starts simply Metropolis City has been destroyed alot of people are dead.  The archvillain who does it has been caught but literally doesnt care and laughs about the fact that the heroes will only just throw him in jail and he will eventualy get out and kill more people.  One superhero....decides....he has had enough and kills this archvillain.
Thats the trailer.....

Unfortunately the game kind of throws you into the rest of the game...by making it so heroes get pulled to another world where those events had happened and it seams things in that world changed....to make the world a not so friendly place.

I really enjoyed the voice acting and the graphic rendering overlays on the actors...the acting isnt too bad....its very thought provoking.

reviewText:
Got this during the sale and I must say it's one of the most fun games both visually and gameplay-wise that I played in awhile.The game is responsive,has incredible interaction with the enviroment,the characters have great and unique moves,has tons of content like 10-15 different modes,single-player,multi-player and very well done tutorial/practice sections with even more bonus missions.

First off,I noticed how well done the actual gameplay is.I like this style even better than the Mortal Kombat series.As you fight,you feel like the enviroment around you is alive because you actually influence it.You can interact with various objects   in many ways depending on the champion you have and it's visually and aesthetically pleasing and also satisfying when you pull that off.''Transitions'' is the name of the special move that you can pull off depending on the map.Basically you kick someone into the side of the map and throw them in another map.It's very well done and again,it makes the enviroment come alive.The characters move smoothly and all their abilities are well done and creative.Each hero has a special ''ultimate ability'' and every single one is satisfying to watch.

The single player campaign is very well done and has a good story for you to follow.Seeing all those characters together,interacting in different ways is nice,but even nicer when you include their evil duplicates.The story has 12 chapters and in every chapter you play with someone else,only Batman has 2 chapters because..he is Batman.The cinametics and dialogue are great and as I said,the story is interesting and with the gameplay,you won't get bored for a second.The only downside is the fact that the actualy storyline+gameplay lasts only for about 2 hours.

Injustice:Gods Among Us features a good single player experience,with tons of additional content like the ''Classic Mode'' in which you need to defeat 10 heroes in 10 matches in a row,the last being Superman thus unlocking a different ending for each individual hero packed with a small story and a small cinematic.

Also,it has Scorpion as a guest character.

reviewText:
GAMEPLAY: The PC port of this game is increasingly infamous for bugs and glitches.  Particularly with key binding.  Several of the minigames in the main story are bugged so that you have to push the default buttons for it to register.  It still shows you the keys that you've set but it won't count if that's what you hit.  Beyond that, combos don't always properly register, even simple ones.  The battle style is rather simple, somewhere between Super Smash Brothers and Soul Calibur.  The combos don't take fifty different buttons and an understanding of calculus to pull off so that's a plus for me.  The moves do get a little repetetive and seem to encourage button mashing at times.

Not everyone seemed to like the story mode but I actually thought that it was pretty well done with some beautiful references to the comics and a few movies/shows.  It felt consistent with the way the characters are in the comics for the most part.  The story mode flows well and increases in difficulty evenly.  I thought it was a great way to get to know the fighters and their individual abilities.  The button issues made that more difficult but it was still manageable.

AUDIO: The music in this game seems a bit broken.  During most of the fight scenes I couldn't hear anything with the volume on maximum.  What I could hear just came across as underwhelming.  The music just wasn't that Impressive, it didn't feel like it added to the story or make the battles feel more intense.  This left me with turning off the game's music and just substituting my own.  The only thing more annoying than the music was the voice work (specifically in battle).  The voices were spot on for the most part, maybe except for Raven which seemed REALLY out of place, but the lines are very limited.  VERY limited.  All of the characters, regardless of costumes, have exactly one opening, one half-life, and one victory line.  That's it.  I don't expect a hundred lines per character but is a half dozen really asking too much?  Especially for ♥♥♥♥ Grayson, the original punny smart mouth.  It just makes the characters feel less deep when they have such a limited vocabulary.  I would have loved it if the characters had more commentary for specific characters, areas, and attack combos.  One of the staples of comics has been the witty banter and it is entirely absent from the free play.  There's a small amount in the story but even that is limited to opening and closing statements.  I just wish there had been more on an auditory level with this game.

In the PC version, all the characters and costumes are already unlocked.  Several of the costumes represent entirely different characters such as Batman's Flashpoint" costume which is actually Thomas Wayne
date: an entirely differnet Batman.  There are a few others that fall under the same category but don't have any difference which takes away some of the immersion.  They are literally costumes and bring nothing to the table that isn't a slight visual cameo.  The audio work in this game really killed it for me.  There was so much ground to cover and I don't even think they reached the bare minimum of what I wanted from it.\n\nVISUAL: The game looks amazing.  The trailers did the work of showing off what the game actually looks like and it maintains consistency between cut scenes and fight scenes.  My biggest issue here was the costuming
recommended: several in particular.  I'll start with my favorite girl
hoursPlayed: Harley Quinn.  I'm annoyed with a few costuming choices but hers in particular with her 'original' look.  I didn't care for it in Batman Arkham Asylum when they made her buxom

It just doesn't make sense.\n\nThe most notable female character in all of DC probably has to be Wonder Woman.  I like all of her costumes in this game except for her Regime costume.  In one scene in particular her chest is laughably oversized.  It's like watching X-Men the Anime all over again.  The way that her costume is cut

It's like they just got off a horse or took a super in their shorts.  They just look awkward. reviewText:
idk what to put so heres a waffle recipe:

Ingredients:

2 eggs
2 cups all-purpose flour
1 3/4 cups milk
1/2 cup vegetable oil
1 tablespoon white sugar
4 teaspoons baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract

Steps:

1.) Preheat waffle iron. Beat eggs in large bowl with hand beater until fluffy. Beat in flour, milk, vegetable oil, sugar, baking powder, salt and vanilla, just until smooth.

2.) Spray preheated waffle iron with non-stick cooking spray. Pour mix onto hot waffle iron. Cook until golden brown. Serve hot.

reviewText:
I like the game, it has pontential.

Pros:

- DC characters, really good pick of characters.  You might think that they only use the 'saxxy popular' characters like Harley Quinn, Catwoman, Batman and Superman, but it's really not like that. For instance, i like Raven, Zatanna and Killer Frost (who aren't so 'saxxy popular' and used in the Arkham series.)

- Good and fun gameplay, stop saying it looks like MK. I like the way every character has a unique power. using the power really helps sometimes, like Harley's present, if You're low on health the present picks Ivy's rose which regenerates some of her health or the Joker picture which Increases attack damage on the opponent. I also like the 'launch' option which helps you in fighting to your opponent. These don't exist in MK.

- The S.T.A.R.S lab missions, they're unique, challenging and fun.

- The fact that you can have a single fight.

- Various Level Transitions and Interactive objects. It's not the typical: Punch, Kick and Stab/Freeze/Shoot/Pummel. These make the game more Fun.

-The game runs on my crappy PC.

- Character's clothes start ripping off when they take damage

- The menu music is catchy.


Cons:

- The WBID iOS B-♥♥♥♥. Really? I have to own an ishitphone to get Harley Quinn's AC outfit? I'd get it if the unlocks are available through the Android version of the app too, but just iOShit? Really?

- Scorpion... Really? Injustice is a GAME not a mod for MK. It really looks more different than MK. Why put Scorpion instead of any other DC character like Robin, Poison Ivy or Starfire?

- Some gameplay mechanics, Combos are really just the way you are going to spam 2 buttons. But also there are the special moves, when i play, i either choose to fight with just combos or just special moves. It's really hard to use them both in one battle, because when i do try, i usually start loosing the match, but maybe it's just me.

- Online fighting.

- Killer Frost, Catwoman's Ame-comi outfit and Batgirl Don't have Hair physics, it looks really stiff and un-realistic.

- Well, the design on men with tights and underwear, they don't have 'ball drops' which makes them look like they don't have  a..... male reproductive organ. (or it's just pervy me)


That's all really. 9.5/10. I really like it and i still play it.

reviewText:
This is my re-review for this game.  When the game first came out, I had a 'do not recommend' rating on it because of the non-working multiplayer and the numerous bugs and crashes, even though my system is well above the recommended specs for this game.  It seems many of these issues have been corrected so I am now recommending based on my recent experience.

Firstly the game screams really bad console port" upon navigating the UI of the game.  Having to use WASD keys to navigate and press "G" to accept options seemed very lazy to me and tells me that there was very little to no effort placed on UI conversion from console to PC.  There appears to be no mouse support at all for UI navigation.  Makes it very confusing unless you are dedicated to using controller only.  Controller support however was very good and the game worked great with my Logitech F310.  This is a minor issue since the 2D fighting games are usually best played with gamepad anyway.

The single player story is actually pretty good for this type of game.  The story explores the concept of an alternate comic reality where the heroes have determined that man cannot rule themselves.  The heroes take on an authoritarian rule and attempt to justify their means as what must be done for the good of man.  The heroes of our universe end-up getting pulled into this "mirror" universe to take on their counterparts and keep the battle from coming to our reality and doing what is right while they are there.  While the story was very good it was also very short.  Took me only 4 hours to complete the single player story and I was taking my time doing it.

The levels are very well designed for a 2D fighter.  The levels have destructible elements and also have various means of interaction that can be used in the fight
date: like kicking a character into an object
recommended: throwing an object or activating a technology item to use against the opponent.  The levels also have transitions where you can smack an opponent through the wall with a nice animation and have land in a different part of the level.  The destructible items
hoursPlayed: object interactions and level transitions are features that make a super themed fighter feel more "super".\n\nThere are also a ton of extra features like S.T.A.R. labs which acts as a sort of challenge mode and allows you to unlock more content.  There is also a practice mode and a quick match mode for those wanting to get a quick versus fight against the AI in.  There are a lot of unlockables in this game like portraits
voteText:
icons and backgrounds for your Hero card.  There is also a lot of unlockable concept art and music as well.  A collector will find a lot of things to do here.

The multiplayer did not work at launch but it appears that these issues have been recently fixed.  I have only played a very small amount of MP but had not trouble finding a match when trying to do so.  I have read reviews where there are still some multiplayer stability and connection issues and the developers have mentioned that further patches to correct these issues are still coming.

The Ultimate Edition comes with all of the previously released DLC characters that were on the console versions of the game.  This is nice since the game will include all of the characters without any more investment.

Once the initial issues were patched the game was fairly enjoyable.  I am not sure that I would recommend paying full price for this title
helpfulPercent: but if you enjoy 2D fighting games then you will probably like this one.  A pretty good buy at the recent 50% sale price that I seen on Steam."

reviewText:
Pros:

+ MK makers at the helm of a DC fighting game = absolute magic
+ Deep roster of DC villains and heroes that each feel unique
+ NetherRealm does it again by bringing a solid, coherent and worthwhile story-mode to a fighting game
+ Multiple game modes, unlocks, and challenges ensures you'll come back again and again after finishing the campaign

Cons:

- Some have an issue with the over-reliance on Batman characters
- Online play has been, and supposedly continues, to be hampered by poor connectivity and balance
- A little overzealous on the DLC front but aside from the additional fighters the other bits don't feel required/necessary

The Bottom Line

Holy Terror Batman! Injustice is a fantastic fighting game that does what MK did in bringing a worthwhile story-mode and deep, fun, and challenging gameplay to the Western fighter genre. In short, Marvel vs Capcom 3 has NOTHING on Injustice and it would be great if NetherRealm took another stab at it with more DC characters later in the future.

9 batarangs out of 10

reviewText:
Injustice is a great for singleplayer fans with the wealth of combat content (Battles mode adds modifiers, the story mode offers a more cinematic experience, there are tons of bonus pieces of concept art and such to unlock in the Archives), but online multiplayer is all but dead now despite High Voltage's efforts to rectify the lackluster matchmaking built into the game. The few times I could connect or tried to play the bonus S.T.A.R. Labs challenge mode also resulted in my keyboard control settings getting reset to default without even telling me. Yes, this is a game apparently so hastily ported that it can't handle customized controls for certain areas of play, even though the default keyboard controls are atrocious and seem to be designed by someone who has never played on a PC before.

This is made up for by great balancing (save for Green Lantern), fluid animation, easy to execute but hard to master combos, and some of the best ideas to open up fighting games to the general masses. Seriously, if you've ever wanted to get into a fighting game but couldn't and like DC, then this is the game for you. They have a full training level, practice mode, and very scalable AI that lets you get better at your own pace. If you are using a controller, then you can even practice most of your combos in the S.T.A.R. Labs for each character and get a better feel for them. There's no sense of shame having to start on Easy once you realize you've got enough memorized to move on up to far greater challenges.

So it's entirely about what you want in a fighting game. Do you enjoy battling AI? Do you enjoy just fighting it out, even if it isn't another human opponent? Then this is an excellent game for you. Do you want to fight people online? Then you're better off getting a console version or the PS Vita version of Ultimate Edition. Do you want to fight with a controller or keyboard? I frankly think you shouldn't have to decide, but that actually impacts your decision here to, sad as it is. I'm going to probably get plenty more hours out of it than I already have; but there are far better, more complete experiences for the same price as this game. Get it on sale if you can, unless the simple idea of a good DC fighting game in of itself is too hard to resist.

reviewText:
If you're looking for a ground breaking fighting game, this isn't it. If however, you are looking for a story or are a fan of Mortal Kombat Komplete edition and how they did their stories, this might be for you.

This game is literally Mortal Kombat Komplete minus the fatalities. The special moves are all still there with an abundance of characters. Abilities vary whereas some may powerup as their special while others may choose a different fighting stance ( such as Wonder Woman going from a lasso to her sword). What I particularly like about this game what made me feel like I was playing MK Deception was the ability to use the environment as a weapon. Some stages have missiles, cars, or barrels hanging around waiting to be tossed at your opponent. Some stages become death traps as you may knock a character off center and into something in the scenery and bounce them back for a combination hit (such as you can kick someone into something in the background and they'll come flying back). My favorite though hands down is in some stages you send someone flying through a wall with a power hit, they go flying through multiple buildings or floors into another stage. The fighting itself is alright with nothing extremely spectacular and difficulty levels are appropriate.

The visuals are neat. Everything is kept clean and the cut scenes are very nice to watch.

I played this game for it's story as it was quite a cliffhanger. I play this once in a while when a friend comes over but as for replayability, not quite here.

It's an average game that will most likely appeal to MK Komplete fans in how they ran their story.

Rating : 7/10

reviewText:
It's all down to one word: yes or no?

Well, this game is really great. Story mode's okay, the battle mode is actually pretty good and the leveling system's nice too. The graphics are great (considering the game uses the Unreal engine) and the gameplay is pretty nice too. You can use a wide variety of characters and skins for said characters. The voice acting is stellar. WBID unlocks are okay, and the controls are actually pretty easy to learn. (the key combo for special moves can get a little hard to memorize however, you may have to write down the key combos)

My final verdict on this game shall be a 9.75/10. It was a lot of fun to play and NetherRealm really did great with this game.

reviewText: Absolutly love this game, bought it for £13.50 on sale! Game is packed full of content and is worth the £40, but i was lucky enough to get it for £40. The game is an amazing fighting game which i love to play with friends, its very very fast and combos are easily executed. However i do not really like the single player campaign, it is a nice addition but i buy fighting games for the actual fighting, not story. Decent story but a bit meh at times. The worst thing about this in my opinion is the stupid mini games they have added, they are a waste of time and you have to do them in the story else you wont progress and if you fail them you will have a penalty in the next fight, ie health reduction. I do not like that idea at all, but apart from that the game is amazing, online play is near to perfect on a smooth connection. Played some online games and there is a slight delay with combo-ing, i have noticed but only in longer combos. Apart from that i ♥♥♥♥ing love this game to bits and will carry on playing it for a long time.

reviewText:
As you can probably see by looking at my library, Injustice is my first fighting game on Steam - or on PC in general for that matter so I have nothing to conpare it to. I usually wait a bit more time to give a game a thorough review but I find that fighting games, initially don't require as much time to review (as say for example an rpg, or adventure game). Especially since fighting games typically have a short story/single player campaign/arcade mode that you can finish rather quickly. That being said, this review is going to be based solely on the single player portions of the game. Sorry guys, take a look at my library, I'm not a multiplayer kind of guy...

Injustice is a Fighting game set in the universe if DC Comics and is brought to you by the makers of the Mortal Kombat franchise.

In Injustice's case, the game has a great presentation. The story mode is probably the most well done story mode I've seen in a fighting game. The campaign allows you to experience a well written dialogue worthy of the DC Comic's name brand, the scenes transition seemlessly in the fights. There is a fine balance between the story, the fights, quick time events and mini-games to break the repetitiveness that may occur and Injustice does this exceedingly well. Keeping things fresh for gamers all around.

The controls are buttery smooth, they feel natural and are never flailing. There seems to be no lag or delay between button response and character's reaction to them. There are different levels of a.i fighters and each of them are executed well, leaving for alot of replayability and player growth.

There is a good array of characters to choose from. Pretty much the biggest names of DC Comics and a few not so much. Whether you're a fan of the heroes or a fan of the villains, there's something here for you, although to be honest I did find myself at times, wanting more. Moving on, there is a fair amount of unlockables to keep playing for so other than just mastering each character, there is alot of replayability to be had through unlockables -such as Hero cards- and a sly feature mode called Star Labs.

One thing I did find to be a tad odd was the developer's choice to not include a blocking mechanic in-battle. You don't have a block button, it's just a bit strange but the gameplay is fun enough to keep this from becoming any real issue.

I myself, am a big fan of the DC Comic's universe had to purchase this game eventually. I like the watching the shows Arrow, The Flash, Legends Of Tomorrow and Gotham, I also own all of the Arkham games as well as the Lego Batman games as well so hopefully this fees my DC Comic hunger for a bit until something new comes out.

I recommend this game if you are a fan of DC Comics and Mortal Kombat type fighting. Of course, the moves aren't as brutal but the feelingis very similar to that of Mortal Kombat.

Review based on the current build of the single-player portions of the game, bought at a conveniently low pricepoint.

reviewText: Whenever  a game is ported to PC, one must be wary of it, for the PC occasionally gets the shaft. Injustice: Gods Among Us is quite the opposite in my personal opinion.\n\nI'll start out by discussing the single-player of the game. The story is fairly interesting, but it isn't exactly the most riveting tale in my opinion. It's pretty straightforward, and there are not really any surprise twists that make it seem any less generic. With that said however, it does provide a good 4-5 hours of fun. It may seem like that is incredibly short, but there is more to single-player. Battle mode is an interesting feature than has you facing several foes in a row with various modes. For example, there is one mode that has you facing all villains, another all heroes, and another facing several random foes with only a quarter of your health. These are fairly challenging, and do make the game worth playing outside of the campaign. Additionally, there are missions under the heading STAR Labs"

reviewText:
I'd like to start off this guide by saying this game may or may not work on your system. Many users have reported having a plethra of issues ranging from resolution problems, to issues where the game refuses to run. By this game at your own risk.

This game costs $22 at the time when I bought it. For 5 hours gameplay, it was a dissapointment. I was expecting ATLEAST 10 hours, but I could see how it would become boring with such a linear gameplay. The game first wouldn't go above 800x600 @ 75Hz in the options menu, but after some mucking around within the ini file I got it working. I understand this is a ported version from the PC but these kinds of issues are not exceptable. It seems every year, another superhero game is released that is just covered in issues or just a pay to win game. This game was no exception.

Buy this game if you are a DC fan, or if you've read the Injustice comic series. If not, save yourself. This is not a good fighter by any measure of the imagination.

reviewText:
Public Review on behalf of the Opium Pulses Steam group
Few words about the game
Enjoyable fighting game full of DC superheroes with great single-player content and quite demanding multi-player. I didn't played enough of fighting games before so I might miss few points you look for, but I still can easily recommend this game to everyone around just to try it out. It have everything you might require from fighting game - plenty of character to choose from (missing some minor DC heroes), good graphics, lots of combos to learn and, what I liked most, high level of enviroment interaction. Must-have for every DC fan.

Advantages
Fighting system is full of combos and sweet moves with super powers usage
Graphics are quite good looking with nicely detailed enviroment
Level design is almost perfect and fun, full of interactive elements and possible transitions to 2nd part of the level
Characters design is even better, properly recreated look and behavior of all 30 DC characters you can play as, along with nicely done relations between allies and enemies
Multiplayer is working properly for me and it's suprisingly hard, guess I'm really bad at fighting games but it's hard to keep up with some of players that I was matched with
Rich single-player content - you can choose between story mode, few types of arcade modes and mission mode. It also explains some relations between characters (for players not familiar with DC universe)
Disadvantages
Just as I thought, hard to play without a controller
Low activity in multi-player
FPS drops occur from time to time
In my opinion low balance between few characters
Not all DC characters are in game so I guess some people will be disappointed not seeing their favourite ones

If you find my review helpful or funny be sure to follow Opium Pulses curator page right here for more reviewed games!

reviewText:
Injustice is like Mortal Kombat (9) but without all the fancy stuff; there are no fatalities (why would there be ?) and there are no x-ray moves. What it does have are power struggles where you run at each other at high speed and try to beat the other one up. It's basically just pressing a button but it does look cool. It just doesn't manage to impress. I expected more epic battles.

Knocking someone through the stage is cool (not only cool looking, see ?), however and using the environments to damage your opponents definitely keeps things fresh and exciting.

The story itself is good, as is the voice acting. The graphics are hit and miss; the environments can look beautiful but the characters miss some fine detail and the faces are a bit messed up if you ask me.

Still, there's plenty of gameplay to be found here. The story can be completed in 4-5 hours. After that, you can still do tens of missions, battle your friends or strangers and collect artwork, outfits and things like that. If you're really into fighters I think there's enough gameplay to keep you playing for at least another 15 hours.

In the end, Injustice is no Mortal Kombat, but as long as you can keep that in mind you'll have a great time with it ! Recommended !

[Rating: 72/100]

reviewText:
I love DC comics and I've always loved the idea of seeing Superman become evil. With Injustice, it finally came true. The comics are excellent, and the idea of making the conclusion in the form of a game like this was one of the best I've seen. The game itself is great, as it has a Mortal Kombat-esque gameplay (not much of a surprise since it's the same team), it has an amazing art direction and the voice acting is super.

However, it has a few downsides. The PC port, while it looks waaaay better than its console counterparts, has all of the cinematics locked to 720p, which looks watered down after seeing the game itself run in 1080p with amazing effects and HD textures. The multiplayer doesn't work properly, and some of the achievements are bugged.

All in all, adding all DLC in a single pack for this release was a good bonus, so I'd say it's worth buying when it's on sale. If you own a console, it's worth even its full price.

reviewText:
Not the best fighter I ever played, but definitely fun and packed full of single player content.

The fighting system is based on premade combos that can be combined together with the normal and special moves to result in a crazy combo.
It's not like some fighters (Guilty Gear or Street Fighter) that have no premade combos, but offer more options to chain the normal moves. The result is that Injustice's gameplay  would be closer to a Tekken or a Mortal kombat.

Multiplayer isn't that bad, but like many games which have been around for long, the people left are often veterans, making it noob-unfriendly.

I am still bummed that some of my favorite DC characters are not in it. No Supergirl, Starfire or Brainiac for instance. But I guess it was impossible to please everybody when electing the roster.

The Pros : 30 characters. Famous ones from DC no less.
Good fighting system. Based around premade combos but offer options to chain them.
Lots of single player content. (story, various arcade" modes
date: mission mode)\nYou can interact with the environment during the fight. Interactions change depending on your character type (agile
hoursPlayed:
gadget-based...).
Multiplayer exists and works decently
You can play as (character you like here)
The Cons : You might like it better when a game has no premade combos
The environment interactions are most of the time enabled. Could be a problem for those who don't like that system.
Multiplayer not very active and not revolutionary in general.
"Character powers" (specific mechanic on a button) are not as unique as in Blazblue
(character you like here) might not be playable.
The game is currently on sale for 5 euros. It is just incredible value.
Unless you are allergic to superheroes and/or fighting games with premade combos

reviewText: Great story mode. Aside from the story mode there are lots of different staged battles to explore as well as various modes that test your fighting ability. It will keep you playing for a long time if you enjoy the DC universe. Good tutorial, although there is one part that your timing needs to be perfect in order for you to execute the move and continue on. Multiplayer is decent, not great, but not bad. Your online match can desynchronise from time to time even when both players have a solid connection. I'd play with my friend sometimes 15 matches in a row though with no problem, while other times every couple of matches it would desync. If you notice lag, that isn't the game, it's a weak connection from either you or the person you're playing against or both. Surprisingly, even if there is a plethora of lag the game often won't desync, instead it seems to desync for no reason when everything is going smoothly. Graphics are great. Music is fitting. Block with back, not with right trigger like in Mortal Kombat. There are many different costumes from various comics and eras, of which some characters have more than others. My personal opinion, I feel some of the characters in this game can be a little unbalanced when matched against certain other characters. Overall I think this is a worthwhile purchase, you get a packed game at a price that isn't too bad, and of course even better when on sale for $5.

reviewText: It's always nice to see a fighting game come out on PC. However, the PC thing is only half good, since I have to recommend for all PC users to stay away from the game. The port is horribly done in that many users will experience gameplay in slow motion even on very high end machines with no real permanent fix and no patch in sight. I consider this a broken port and hardly playable at all.\nThat said, the visuals in this game are pretty spectacular and I like the character-pecific design of the moves as well. The gameplay is on the defend by moving backwards variety, there are several types of cancels, each character has a list of special moves and a super move as well as a special ability. The stages feature interactive objects which can enhance mobility and deal damage as well as stage transitions presented in impressive cinematics. Unfortunately not only can the high damage stage interactions be a balance problem in competitive play but the cinematics for super moves and stage transitions are very long, unskippable and always the same, as are the entrances and victory animations that you'll be forced to watch over and over and quickly lose their wow-factor.\nTL;DR The game is good but not great, however the port is broken and you shouldn't buy it.

reviewText: I guess Injustice can be best described as a refined Mortal Kombat 9 (a game I enjoyed a lot actually) as such I will reference MK9 a fair bit in the following paragraphs. Also, you might want to know I prefer older, simpler fighting games over the more complex new ones of today (given the chance to play Super Turbo or USFIV I would always go for ST). I am telling you all this, because as refined as Injustice may be, I had considerably less amounts of fun with it, compared to it's sort of" prequel MK9.\n\nMy main gripes with Injustice can be separated into two categories: gameplay and presentation. Let us talk about gameplay first. Injustice plays somehow more clunky than the previous Mortal Kombats. There are many design decisions that changed the game into a direction that I find less enjoyable to play than MK9. One of the big selling points of Mortal Kombat had always been the huge characters and the somewhat up close and personal fighting. For whatever reason the characters in Injustice are about half the size of the fighters from MK9 - now

reviewText:
9/10: One of the best fighting games I have ever played, especially with friends! Even my almost game-illiterate girlfriend has enjoyed playing this with me.

The Great:
The roster of characters
The actual variety between characters' styles
The game modes, especially the ability to just fight individual matches between opponents.

The Good:
The combos are relatively intuitive and easy to learn
The arenas
The interaction with the scenery - which is rather wooden and limited at times, however
The ability to display combos out of the moves list onto the fighting screen itself as part of the HUD, making learning and practising moves much easier

The Meh;
The storymode is rather dry, and is almost summed up simply in the ladder fight mode
The Ultimate Edition extra characters are mostly tedious
The costumes are not that exciting, and cannot be seen when selecting characters so it is hard to know what they all look at without going through a separate menu
This leads on to the rather clumsy menu screens which are less than intuitive

The Bad:
Very little, besides the rather superfluous and often tedious 'extra' game modes/challenges for each character that bear no relation to the fighting game, are mere fan service, and for the most part seem to be clumsy and awkward

My Summary:
The game is great fun, especially with friends in local coop, like all the best fighting games. It suffers from the usual story mode dryness and silliness, and as it is made by the people behind Mortal Kombat 9 share many of the mechanics and even basic story elements of that game (both the good, bad and ugly you might say). However, it feels a lot more welcome in this universe, and the explanation behind the excessive violence is satisfying and the lack of fatalities and brutalities - all be it the Super Moves kind of count as an X-Ray move and are still over the top, but not too bad for superheroes - means that it is more believable as to how the fighters survive. There are some interesting moments in the story, and the characters are well voiced for the most part. Head nods to iterations in games, movies, tv shows, and famous comic series - especially in regard to their costumes - abound. This game is thoroughly good fun and a must for fans of fighting games, superheroes, or anything like that especially.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Injustice is a great for singleplayer fans with the wealth of combat content (Battles mode adds modifiers, the story mode offers a more cinematic experience, there are tons of bonus pieces of concept art and such to unlock in the Archives), but online multiplayer is all but dead now despite High Voltage's efforts to rectify the lackluster matchmaking built into the game. The few times I could connect or tried to play the bonus S.T.A.R. Labs challenge mode also resulted in my keyboard control settings getting reset to default without even telling me. Yes, this is a game apparently so hastily ported that it can't handle customized controls for certain areas of play, even though the default keyboard controls are atrocious and seem to be designed by someone who has never played on a PC before.

This is made up for by great balancing (save for Green Lantern), fluid animation, easy to execute but hard to master combos, and some of the best ideas to open up fighting games to the general masses. Seriously, if you've ever wanted to get into a fighting game but couldn't and like DC, then this is the game for you. They have a full training level, practice mode, and very scalable AI that lets you get better at your own pace. If you are using a controller, then you can even practice most of your combos in the S.T.A.R. Labs for each character and get a better feel for them. There's no sense of shame having to start on Easy once you realize you've got enough memorized to move on up to far greater challenges.

So it's entirely about what you want in a fighting game. Do you enjoy battling AI? Do you enjoy just fighting it out, even if it isn't another human opponent? Then this is an excellent game for you. Do you want to fight people online? Then you're better off getting a console version or the PS Vita version of Ultimate Edition. Do you want to fight with a controller or keyboard? I frankly think you shouldn't have to decide, but that actually impacts your decision here to, sad as it is. I'm going to probably get plenty more hours out of it than I already have; but there are far better, more complete experiences for the same price as this game. Get it on sale if you can, unless the simple idea of a good DC fighting game in of itself is too hard to resist.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: My quick review of this game is it's not as good as the latest Mortal Kombat, but it's fun enough to warrant a purchase.  The neat thing about this game is you can send your enemies flying into different stages which causes extra damage.  The stages all have interactable objects to inflict pain.  For instance in the Batcave, you can use the Batmobile to fire rockets at the other player if you're near the computer console.  It has a story mode very similar to Mortal Kombat where you play different characters for 4 fights and then switch characters.  They added in minigames for the story which isn't much, but at least adds something to the fights.  If you win the minigames, the opponent starts with less health.  It has online and everything with different modes (but I haven't really checked that out.)  The one big complaint I have of this game is it ties in with the mobile game.  It doesn't affect the gameplay, but it does lock certain playercard artwork.  Basically you have to login to the mobile app beat the battles in it to unlock more artwork.  The mobile app looks amazing it just takes up 1GB of space on your phone and in my opinion the game isn't great enough to warrent that.  Overall, if you're a fan of fighting games this is a must have for your collection and if you're a fan of DC Comics I'd recommend checking this out.

reviewText:
Injustice is a good fighting game, real fun to play once you figure out how the game works. I recommend this game to any gamers who play fighting games. As a newbie to fighting games, i found it really hard to chain combos (or something like that, idk)(or maybe its just obvious im new to fighting game) so i spent countless of hours playing practice mode till my left thumb get tired. Theres a ton of side quest mission in this game  (STAR labs mission) for each of the characters in Injustice, some of them are really hard to complete. The story is quiet good imo, although its pretty short. I was quiet impressed with the soundtrack, especially the main theme.

****BUT****

yup, there's a 'but' about this game. If you're like me, who live in Asia and looking to battle online, then i DO NOT recommend buying injustice. Right now, i cant seem to battle other players because of constant disconnect. Every time im in character select, 90% of the time i got message 'The game session is no longer available'. I tried to search for the fix, but i only found out that its because of region block or something. I hope my review is helpful to anyone who plan to buy injustice in asia region.

reviewText: Another entry from Netherrealm studios, the makers of the Mortal Kombat franchise. This game borrows heavily from MK9's combo system, but adds it own unique mechanics to the DC universe. A decently fun fighting game but its held back from reaching the upper echelon, by its wonky input system, i.e certain moves buffering into others, causing numerous missed or incorrect attacks. This game also boggles my mind as to why the combo system is so heavily scaled the more hits you put into a combo. I understand they didnt want players to have Touch of Death (T.O.D) combos for balance reasons, but they have other mechanics in place to prevent that from happening, like the clash system. It just feels wrong to di a long combo and have it deal less damage than a shorter more efficient one. Overall its a fun game, with some silly design choices

reviewText:
My first impressions after a few hours of playing:

++++Animations
Among the best I have seen in videogaming

+++Mechanics
TIght, immersive, somehwhat deep and fluent

+Graphics
Solid visuals albeit lacking details, last gen roots are showing

+Sound
You'll feel like watching an AAA blockbuster but the shouts, lines and the score get repetitive fast

+Innovative online lobby-system albeit not fully fleshed out

--------------------------------------------

-Finding online matches is not as fluent as it could be

-Menus are kinda sluggish to navigate

-Not enough variety in offline play



All in all, this game is a solid 8/10 and a guaranteed bombshell for couch playing sessions when friends are over. Seeing your favourite comic heroes battling it out with style is a visually satisfying experience and the character models are definitely not to scoff at, paired with superb animation work there are moften than not fantastic pictures to behold during the fights

Where it does not shine as bright as it could, is the single and online play. At this price point though (7€), it is an absolute steal.

reviewText:
Netherrealm Studios has done a really good job with Injustice. It has taken the best from Mortal Kombat and upgraded it in every way (story, controls, cut scenes, special moves, different modes, unlockable content). I think it's hard to make a good game in such a repetitive and shallow genre as fighting, but this one has a lots of content and features that will take several hours of your time. IMO, currently, Injustice is the best fighting game on PC. Capcom could learn a thing or two from it.

And with the current price (with or w/o the discount), it's really a great purchase.

The only thing that this game lacks is active multiplayer community.

Overall rating: 9/10.

reviewText:
Injustice: Gods Among Us is a DC Comics-themed fighting game that plays with the fluid, easy to learn controls of a modified Mortal Kombat system.  Many of DC's most iconic characters make it to the well-balanced roster and many of the others might show up to beat the ♥♥♥♥ out of your character if you allow your opponent to knock you through the stage's boundaries.

Injustice's story mode is an enjoyable one, similar to Mortal Kombat in the sense that you play as one character in the story for a chapter and kick ♥♥♥ with them before moving onto the next.  Though I am not a DC Super Fan and may be incorrect in this statement, the story mode is an entirely new one written for this game with an exciting turn that answers one of the most popular what-if questions ever posed.

I would highly recommend this game to DC fans looking for a solid fighting game as well as those who have enjoyed the more recent Mortal Kombat games (9 and X).  However, do make sure to take a look at the game's specs as it does take a fairly decent computer to run it without hitting lag spikes in certain situations.

reviewText:
I'm really enjoying this game at the moment. Graphics are nice, voice acting is solid (even in german), gameplay is fun,...

Biggest surprise for me is the campaign mode that delivers a really good story with a lot of cut-scenes. I can't remember another fighting game where I mainly played it because of the story.

Sure, there are also a few weird moments but the heck, it's sometimes EPIC what you get there.

In the forums there is a lot of rage about the multiplayer but for me it worked well. Not perfect (you have to wait a few mins to be able to play a match) but it's ok.

Go for it if you like fighting games and even if it's not your most favourite genre, you will see a lot of super heroes and villians and experience a well made story.
