reviewText:
Who would win a fight: Batman or Superman? It's an age-old question for comic book fans, and the reason a game like Injustice: Gods Among Us Ultimate Edition exists. We want to see our favorite heroes and villains beat the snot out of each other.

Developer NetherRealm Studios finds a suitably comic book way for this to happen, using a dimension-hopping story to smash alternative versions of familiar characters against one another. It's a conceit typical of the DC Comics multiverse, but it opens the door for Injustice's greatest strength—its story mode.

Much like its stablemate Mortal Kombat: Komplete Edition, Injustice's main single-player mode is an eight-hour campaign told from multiple perspectives. Each chapter puts you in control of a different character—including the villains—and mixes up traditional 1 vs 1 fights with QTE minigames. The story mode autosaves at each fight so if you lose you can quickly start again, but transitions between smooth 60fps fights and the pre-rendered 30fps movie cinematics can be a little jarring. That said, the story's quality compares pretty well to the recent Justice League animated series—it's not Shakespeare, but I wanted to find out what was going to happen next.

NetherRealm has streamlined its typical MK fighting engine into a four-button configuration. Each of the game's 30 characters have light, medium, and heavy attacks as well as a quick button for a “character trait” power. Batman summons robot bat-droids, while Green Lantern glows, well, green, and hits harder for a short time. You can throw enemies with a simple tap, or, if your Super Power gauge is full, use an ultra combo that launches into a character-specific cutscene of carnage. It's nice that these spectacles are easy to pull off, especially compared to more complicated fighting games, and I'll never tire of launching a foe into near-earth orbit as Superman, then slamming them back down for massive damage. But their ease of use also means you'll see these cutscenes a lot.

Each stage also includes interactive elements: massive rockets to throw, thrones you can bounce an enemy off of. Aquaman's Atlantis level, for example, lets you shatter its sides to drown your foe in a massive tidal wave. Many levels have secondary areas as well. With a well-timed kick, I sent Hawkgirl tumbling forcefully through the outer walls of Wayne Manor, right through to the mansion's dining room. The interactivity enhances the over-the-top comic violence on display, as does the sound of each brutal hit connecting. I feel like a superhero while playing, leaving wanton destruction in my wake.

Outside of Battle mode, which offers a wide variety of ladder-style challenges, Injustice's big time sink is S.T.A.R. Labs, where you try to complete more than 240 character-specific challenges that serve to teach you the game's more complex techniques. Points earned here and in other modes let you unlock concept art, music, and more in the Hall of Justice Archives. Notably, new character skins are already unlocked in Ultimate Edition, as are the console version's six DLC characters.

Injustice's longevity is tied to its multiplayer, which unfortunately is an issue. Local battles work without a hitch, but are limited to one-on-one fights. Online is a different story: finding someone to play against often doesn't work (whether due to matchmaking issues or lack of a player base is unclear), and when it does, the incredible levels of input lag make the fight frustrating. King Of The Hill and Survival modes sound great, but unless the lag issues are resolved soon, they're wasted.

If NetherRealm can get its online issues sorted, Injustice could be a top-notch fighting game.There's a tremendous amount of content here, including a ton of easter eggs for fans in both Story mode and unlockable content. It'd be a shame if no one plays it.

All in all, a great fighting game with extremely well-known characters using a familar fighting engine. Mortal Kombat vets should feel right at home with Injustice.

Highly Recommended
Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!

reviewText:
To do this review, we need  to numerate three points: 1-STORY 2-FUN 3-GRAPHICS

1-STORY: Injustice brought us a simply recipe to make good video games, but the fact who make this game so incredible is the dynamic between the characters, using the main characters of DC Universe in a arc where Superman Kills Lois Laine and his unborn son because a poison made by Joker, this cause a creation of a Parallel Universe where Superman take control of the earth and all the superheroes, the only superheroe who is contrary about the superman's method to engage them in a dark government is Batman, who created a regime against superman. All the important heroes and villains appear, including Lex Luthor, Aquaman, Joker, Harlequin, Cyborg, Deathstroke, etc. This is one of the best part in the game, the player is got caught in the story and don't want to finish it.

2-FUN: Injustcie was made by Netherrealm Studios, famous for create the Mortal Kombat 9 in 2011 and Mortal Kombat X (is got to be launch in fall 2015) the gameplay is very easy to learn and the movements is the key to victory, some characters has special abilities, like Nightwing, he can transform his bat in two weapons and aquaman, who can use his fork to attack and even grab the opponent. The scenarios was based in DC Universe famous locations, such as the batcave, metropolis, atlantis, the JLA Tower and etc.

3-GRAPHICS: this is the less important point, but I need to talk about, the graphics are not the best in the game world, textures and shadows apparently were not finished, but this not interfere in the gameplay or in the history.

FINAL CONSIDERATIONS:
INJUSTICE is a great game and I recommend it, if you want a game to play alone, multiplayer and with your friends, Injustice is a good alternative between the rivalry Street Fighter x Mortal Kombat

reviewText: Okay where to start? With only a few hours on the game I have come to a reasonable and thoughtful conclusion;\nInjustice; Ultimate Edition runs smoothly, smoother than the original one - giving a better run game. The twist on SuperMan is intense, bringing a darker atmosphere into the DC Universe; rather than the typical mind-controlling larky that SuperMan has usually... Ultimate Edition brings in an additional six playable characters which ultimately fulfils ever DC fans fantasy. I love the unique power-mechanism that each character has, making each character diverse and fun to play - rather than keeping them all rather similar. The FPS on a decent computer is great, making the gameplay look fantastic at most times - apart from spikes that can arise, for instance when a cutscene kicks off etc.\nNethertheless, the game is near perfect for a DC Universe fan - including fights with super powers and god-like skills, I would recommend this to many people - even with a few hours played, I can specifically say that this game is PERFECT for fans!

reviewText: Okay where to start? With only a few hours on the game I have come to a reasonable and thoughtful conclusion;\nInjustice; Ultimate Edition runs smoothly, smoother than the original one - giving a better run game. The twist on SuperMan is intense, bringing a darker atmosphere into the DC Universe; rather than the typical mind-controlling larky that SuperMan has usually... Ultimate Edition brings in an additional six playable characters which ultimately fulfils ever DC fans fantasy. I love the unique power-mechanism that each character has, making each character diverse and fun to play - rather than keeping them all rather similar. The FPS on a decent computer is great, making the gameplay look fantastic at most times - apart from spikes that can arise, for instance when a cutscene kicks off etc.\nNethertheless, the game is near perfect for a DC Universe fan - including fights with super powers and god-like skills, I would recommend this to many people - even with a few hours played, I can specifically say that this game is PERFECT for fans!

reviewText:
Some good mix between Mortal Kombat games and DC Comics story here.
My overall impression is that this game is pretty good, much better than most NetherRealm games Ive played, maybe because of the appeal that the comics superheroes have in old schoolers like me.
The fighting mechanics are basic Mortal Kombat-esque, which means you have to imput back, back + punch to perform a fireball and so on. A few Street Fighter stuff was add, for example: you press back to block (there is no block button) and you can set the special attacks to hadouken like motions, a-la Street Fighter. There also some new mechanics, like the stage interactions (really overpowered), armour moves, fireball combos e many others.
Lets go to some pros and cons:
Pros:
- Very Good and Catchy Story Mode, with a very good comic book plot. The ending is kinda predictable, but its good nevertheless.
- Very good cast, with and interesting selection os DC comics classic heroes and villains, like Batman, Superman, Joker, Wonder Woman, Green Lantern, Harley Quinn, Lobo, Zod, etc...
- Some good and easy to perform combos, that work well if you are a gamepad user, like me. Seems like the developers actually though about us, gamepad guys!
- Some chars have some really interesting alternate outfits, like the Red Son (communist superman), Batman Beyond, General Zod, from the Man of Steel movie, etc..

Cons:
- Seems like no one actually plays this game online, the community is small and its hard to find people to play againts online, which is a mojor problem for a fighting game.
- The cast is good and large, but some chars are just too strong (Superman) and others are very weak (Bane). Its really umbalanced.
- The zoning/fireball game of some character is too strong and broken and some battles are basically who spams fireballs faster. It makes chars without fireballs completelly unplayable.
- Character with superstrength (Superman, Wonder Woman) can interact with the environment to throw cars and objects on others to deal big damage, while non super chars (Batman, Flash) cant do it at all. The stage interactions are really unbalanced and broken towards super strength chars.

In a general way, its a good game. I Rate it 3.8/ 5.0.

reviewText: Injustice: Gods Among Us Ultimate Edition enhances the bold new franchise to the fighting game genre from NetherRealm Studios. Featuring six new playable characters, over 30 new skins, and 60 new S.T.A.R. Labs missions, this edition packs a punch. In addition to DC Comics icons such as Batman, The Joker, Green Lantern, The Flash, Superman and Wonder Woman, the latest title from the award-winning studio presents a deep original story. Heroes and villains will engage in epic battles on a massive scale in a world where the line between good and evil has been blurred.

reviewText:
3/10

DISCLAIMER : THIS GAME DOES NOT HAVE A FUNCTIONAL ONLINE MODE ON PC. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME FOR ONLINE MULTIPLAYER. IT WILL NOT WORK.

While Injustice was an interesting step for Netherrealm Studios between Mortal Kombat 9 and Mortal Kombat X, it failed to live up to the hype, betrayed its own premise with weak writing and falls flat simply as a fighting game, with boring mechanics that don't know what to be and an insipid power system that doesn't do enough on certain characters and does too much on others.

(+) Solid roster
(+) Good story mode...

(-) ...but bad story to accompany it
(-) Story mode has some really bad/boring QTEs that shouldn't be here
(-) Mediocre combat mechanics
(-) Level transitions and level hazards are overpowered (can be turned off)
(-) Very repetitive nature of the combat (by fighting games standards)
(-) Questionable artistic decisions combined with mediocre models
(-) Busted netcode

reviewText:
This game is easy to get into, but devilishly hard to master which is great. The character roster is fantastic with an interesting variation of characters, and they even managed to make Aquaman cool and interesting which is a massive achievement. There is so much stuff to unlock and hidden secrets in the levels, that even the single player mode has a relatively long lifespan. I'm a grown man and I got the chills, when I as Batman kicked Superman through a helicopter and then proceeded to summon the Batmobile to run over him.

The amount of bad assery this game contains, is so enormous that Stephen Hawking tried to calculate it's mass and realized he would have to create a new type of measurement system in order to somehow explain the staggering amount in a way that the average Joe would somehow understand. The closest he could come up with was {q + [q2 + (r-p2)3]1/2}1/3= The amount of Bad assery IGAU contains to the power of infinite.

PC gamers so rarely get good fighting games, that everyone who even remotely likes them should buy this right now to show them our support and maybe we will get more in the future.

On a side note, everyone playing online is a bad ♥♥♥ of epic proportions and keeps wiping the floor with me, go easy on me you 38 fingered godlike metahuman ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ gamers!

reviewText: Just to be clear, I wouldn't consider myself a fighting game fan. However; when I heard the praise Nether Relm were getting for Mortal Kombat, it piqued my interest in their DC fighting game Injustice: Gods Among Us. What grabbed my attention even more was the fact that it had a decent story mode! Well I can say I'm enjoying it immensely, and has definitely opened up my potential appreciation of the genre. The combat is fast, fluid and intuitive, with a wide range of well animated and flashy moves that are both unique and reflective of the characters. The roster, on that note, is top notch - little dissappointed in the absence of some of my personal favourites like Poison Ivy, Scarecrow, Starfire and Beastboy - but the characters that are available are varied and interesting to say the least. The inclusion of all the DLC characters is very nice indeed.\nAs for the PC port, I've played both on xbox 360 and PC, and it definitely looks and runs better on PC (as expected!) The overall quality is vastly improved, as well as silky smooth performance giving constant 60 fps. There are a decent amount of options, though more would be appreciated. Full controller support is available, which is nice as I prefer to use one in this case - However; I will note that the keyboard menu controls are rather wonky, a somewhat bizzarre choice of keys for certain actions, and unfortunately no mouse controlled menus :(\nOverall I urge you to give it a try, or at least look in to it more. If you're a fan of DC you'll enjoy it hands down - And if you're a bit skeptical of fighting games well fear not, there is a wealth of content to keep you occupied! I absolutely reccomend it.

A very fast pace fighting game with destructible environments.

Gameplay - 10 - 30 characters each with different unique styles.

Contents - 10
Balance - 7?  (seriously this can only be answered after you send 500hours into a game so could have some good POV about this.)

Fun factors for single player or local 1vs1  - 9.
Online - not so sure (this score is changing day by day, and highly depending on the life of the net community and the administration from developers).

Dont ask me about street fighter. for some reasons, I dont like SF for years.

reviewText:
Yes I know i'm reviewing yet Another Beat em up

Made by the same guys that brought you Mortal Kombat Komplete Edition, Injustice is set in the DC Universe, where strange things are a foot, not really gonna say much about the story as I think it's one of the better elements and you should see it for yourself instead of having someone read it too you

or Youtube it

ok, so why buy this game?

firstly it's one of the most complete Beat em up's available and builds on the combo styling of MK9, each character has there own move set and super move basd on the hero in question

such as Green Arrows super button , fire's his bow and is used for equipping special arrows such as flaming, freezing and electric

while batmans summons robo bats to use as a shield or projectiles, or wonder womans swaps between lasso or sword and shield

So each character's moves and specials fit with what you'de expect from them.

here's a big negative though, the game requires a powerful pc to run well, and the graphics can't really be toned down to compansate

but for those that can run this, it's a very good game, while i feel it could have had more modes, the offering is nice

so pro's and con's time

pro's

@ Large Roster, sometimes you won't have heard of certain characters though Cough" Killer Frost "Cough"

con's

reviewText:
The Injustice PC port didn't go as smoothly as the Mortal Kombat 9 port, but it was still able to capture the essence of the game and deliver a product worthy of purchase for fighter fans, NetherRealm fans and hardcore comic book buffs.

Although everything is visually in place and controls are much smoother than the console versions of Injustice, some glitches do lurk in the shadows and can cripple gameplay at times. It's possible to experience issues like the screen going completely black and game joins endlessly looping that require an end task to stop. It also suffers from slightly unpredictable netcode that can sometimes drop a game out of nowhere -- but it's not nearly as bad as MK9.

The PC port is graphically stunning. Seeing this game on Xbox 360 and then on PC nearly made my head explode. Those who want to show off what their Gaben shrines can really do should look no further than this game as proof of their labors.

Overall, the port is solid. The instabilities tend to arrive when transitioning to online play, but they don't happen enough to make me regret my purchase in any way. 8/10

reviewText: I don't play fighting games very much.  I liked Mortal Kombat and Street Fighter from back in the day, but I was that jerk who always picked Blanca and then spammed his forward roll.  I found this one pretty accessible, and a lot of fun.  The characters have some great special moves (Batman can summon his Batmobile to run over his opponent, for example) and the arenas are full of interactable objects.  The single-player eases you into it and tells a little story as you move along.  It's good fun, it's forgiving of newbies, and it gets a thumbs-up from me.

reviewText:
Injustice: Gods Among Us is basically a B-movie about superheroes where you can play most of the cool fighting scenes yourself. Even if you suck at fighting games like I do you can have a lot of fun in single player (on normal) and just button mash your way through the story. The story is not very good but entertaining enough to keep you going.
I haven't touched the MP yet and I'm not really intend to. The controls are sometimes a bit unprecise but you will probably buy this for the single player anyway so don't worry too much about it.
It's definitly worth 5 bucks for the single player alone.

reviewText:
The Injustice PC port didn't go as smoothly as the Mortal Kombat 9 port, but it was still able to capture the essence of the game and deliver a product worthy of purchase for fighter fans, NetherRealm fans and hardcore comic book buffs.

Although everything is visually in place and controls are much smoother than the console versions of Injustice, some glitches do lurk in the shadows and can cripple gameplay at times. It's possible to experience issues like the screen going completely black and game joins endlessly looping that require an end task to stop. It also suffers from slightly unpredictable netcode that can sometimes drop a game out of nowhere -- but it's not nearly as bad as MK9.

The PC port is graphically stunning. Seeing this game on Xbox 360 and then on PC nearly made my head explode. Those who want to show off what their Gaben shrines can really do should look no further than this game as proof of their labors.

Overall, the port is solid. The instabilities tend to arrive when transitioning to online play, but they don't happen enough to make me regret my purchase in any way. 8/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: I don't play fighting games very much.  I liked Mortal Kombat and Street Fighter from back in the day, but I was that jerk who always picked Blanca and then spammed his forward roll.  I found this one pretty accessible, and a lot of fun.  The characters have some great special moves (Batman can summon his Batmobile to run over his opponent, for example) and the arenas are full of interactable objects.  The single-player eases you into it and tells a little story as you move along.  It's good fun, it's forgiving of newbies, and it gets a thumbs-up from me.

reviewText:
Injustice is a game that I waited to get until it was on serious discount, and I'm glad I did. Honestly, it's one of those that is good enough, but you definitely wouldn't want to pay full price for it. The fighting is good, the selection of characters is pretty good (although there are some glaring omissions that would have been preferable to some of the inclusions), and the game itself has more than enough modes and unlockables to keep you amused for a good long while.

Unfortunately, the worst part of it is the story, which most will probably play. It's a filmsy, poorly-written affair that engages too much in going too far, and then gives us nothing satisfying out of it. There are some interesting moments and even exciting moments, but overall it is not only misogynistic, but also clearly written by someone who was completely unaware of the characters or their capabilities. It fails the characters in pretty much every way, and while there are moments that seem thrilling, it's overall a train wreck that employs fridge logic too often.

The story ends up coming off as highly contrived and is just more or less entirely worthless, which is a shame since it's well-animated and the voice acting is excellent. The very premise, though, is extremely questionable, and overall you get a far more interesting experience simply by playing through Battles, the 'arcade mode' of this game. If only the main story had better pacing, even a slight grasp of the characters, and a sense of when things go too far, it would have been vastly improved. It also really could have used a significant amount of work on making the premise more believable and consistent with itself.

The moves are interesting, but not every character is as accessible as one may expect. Some of the special moves, additionally, are kind of ridiculous and some are too graphic and over-the-top, which really takes out of the immersion of fighting. The stages are great, and the gimmicks and interactions are really fun, but there are also some details that also interfere with immersion, such as fighting Doomsday on the stage where, in the background...Doomsday's standing around.

There are at least plenty of modes, though, to keep anyone amused for some time. There's a very thorough training mode, and the game itself is extremely accessible to players of all skill levels. Want to just have fun beating up bad guys? You can do that. Want to be challenged? You can do that too. You'll probably have all kinds of fun in the single match and arcade modes, and there are also challenge missions that will bring further entertainment. The best part of these is that you can usually choose the characters you like, and at the very least it's more believable than the story mode's narrative. Unfortunately, none of the DLC characters have any STAR Labs challenge missions, nor do they have alternate costumes, which seem like significant oversights. It would have been much more fun if they had.

All in all, it's a good game if you ignore its faults and shortcomings. If you're familiar with the characters, you'll be more than a bit annoyed at times by the writing being clearly wrong for them, but if you are looking for a good superhero fighter, you should have some solid fun with this.

reviewText:
I'm not huge into fighting games, but this is loads of fun. It might be because I'm a huge DC fan, but the combat feels heavy and the moves feel unique. There are some balancing issues, but I might be saying this just because I'm not that good. Despite that, it still brings me back to try and perfect certain characters.
The story isn't that great, but the individual moments stand out to me. The characters feel real and sympathetic, and I like the voice acting, it's just too bad that it seems wasted in a lame excuse to get everybody to fight each other.
I doubt anybody buys this for the story though.
My only suggestion is that you look up bug fixes, because there are plenty of those. 10 minutes online will help you fix them, but they're annoying and frequent.
That being said, I'm enjoying myself when the bugs aren't around.

reviewText: If you like fighting games and comic book superheroes, this is a great choice. I admit, I've never been a fan of Mortal Kombat and this game's lineage sort of turned me off of it. Boy, do I wish I got into it sooner. It's very different from what I expected (there is almost no gore and the story makes sense) and I plan on picking it up for Wii U really soon. I've played through the story mode once but would like to again as well as get some buddies together and smash each other. This is the sort of game that doesn't require someone to memorize a ton of combos and special moves. They exist but the game is a bit easier to handle right off the bat. The real shining point is the story mode which is engaging if you like DC and is very unique for a fighting game. I love how cinematics blend seamlessly into fights. Even mini games are occassionally stuck in but unlike bashing sedans on a pier, these games make sense in the story. Try it.

reviewText: Aquaman is actually useful for a change. His moveset is actually one of the best in the game. So if you really want to settle which superhero would win in a fight against each other, this game won't do that for you. On the otherhand, don't expect balanced gameplay either. The special character Scorpion is OP for instance, and so is Aquaman. The reason I love this game is because its fun and the story mode was a blast to play through. If you've ever been exposed to comic books, then you know that an alternate universe where Superman is the bad guy is nothing new, but somehow this game makes it feel fresh even though it isn't. I used a controller when playing the game, and I will say that the pre-set controls for an xbox controller are excellent. Unfortunately, this means that I can't comment on how gameplay works with the keyboard. I'd recommend this game if you like superheroes and DC comics. Bottom line: The story mode was pretty fun to play through, and the gameplay was fun, but beware of balancing issues when playing multiplayer.

reviewText:
I'm not a connoisseur of fighting games, or the DC comic universe, so take this with a grain of salt.

That being said, I had an absolute blast playing this game. The story mode was well written and fun to progress through the different fighters. It's fairly easy to unlock all the battles just by completing the story mode, so that was a bonus to the progression from story to fighting game. Each battle type has certain restrictions placed upon them in order to successfully complete them.

The S.T.A.R.S. missions are another good way to waste some time in the game. They also help with mastering certain fighters and their moves. A good challenge, as they eventually introduce some outside characters (such as Lobo and Scorpion) to add to the roster.

I havent done any online fighting, so no comment will be made on that apart from the daily challenge seems like a great idea to throw some diversity into the mix.

Overall, with me being a mediocre player of fighting games, Injustice: Gods Among Us was incredibly accessible and fun to play. The plethora of game modes makes this a game I will keep coming back to time after time.

reviewText: Aquaman is actually useful for a change. His moveset is actually one of the best in the game. So if you really want to settle which superhero would win in a fight against each other, this game won't do that for you. On the otherhand, don't expect balanced gameplay either. The special character Scorpion is OP for instance, and so is Aquaman. The reason I love this game is because its fun and the story mode was a blast to play through. If you've ever been exposed to comic books, then you know that an alternate universe where Superman is the bad guy is nothing new, but somehow this game makes it feel fresh even though it isn't. I used a controller when playing the game, and I will say that the pre-set controls for an xbox controller are excellent. Unfortunately, this means that I can't comment on how gameplay works with the keyboard. I'd recommend this game if you like superheroes and DC comics. Bottom line: The story mode was pretty fun to play through, and the gameplay was fun, but beware of balancing issues when playing multiplayer.

reviewText:
Let me just say up front:  I'm TERRIBLE at fighting games.  I never could learn all those moves.

That said, I just finished the single-player campaign, and I highly recommend the game.

The Good:
Great story.  Loved every minute of the story.  Sure, the story is on the simple side, but there was a lot of feeling to it.  I'm not a HUGE comic book reader.  I read my last Justice League comic over 20 years ago, so there were a lot of characters I didn't know, but I was familiar enough with the classic characters to get along pretty well.

The fighting was fun.  I'm no good at it.  I button mash a lot, but overall, the gameplay was fun.

Sometimes it seemed to me that the game was PROGRAMMED to beat me the first round, and then get steadily easier each time I lost.  It was a little suspicious, but now that I think about it, it rewarded my lack of skill by giving me a chance to keep playing.  That's actually quite nice, because I could continue the story, even being not good at the game.

I had a few times where I said WTF was THAT!!!" when a character pulled a particular move
date: or did something spectacular that destroyed my character.  The big one was when Doomsday did something outrageous like THIRTY hits on Superman by throwing him through a wall.\n\nStill
hoursPlayed: and I highly recommend it for people who aren't so good at fighting games.  Now that the main campaign is finished

reviewText:
As a DC fan, I was already engrossed to its story since the very beginning of the game. The story felt like a Justice League movie and it was a very good attempt to spice up the content in the midst of battles, Well, it does have the flashpoint paradox vibes during my playthrough. The combat felt good and I will highly recommend players who are new to fighting games to try out easy or at most medium settings to get the feel of the game. Do get a responsive gamepad when you play this as enemies will pounce on you within seconds to break your moves.

However, the story is really short, you shoud clear this on the same day you purchased it. I completed the story mode in less than 5 hours at a casual pace and felt that the story could have been alot longer, maybe even doubled. In addition, during character selection before a match, there are no way to see previews of your alternate skins of your heroes which will probably be a little better if they have added that function.

All in all, Injustice is a very good gme and it is currently on sold at a discounted price. I bought it for half of what it is now but it is still worth the money to play for DC fans and even neutrals.

reviewText:
I wasn't sure about Injustice:Gods Among Us.

I might not have bought it if I hadn't been on sale. While I love DC, I don't tend to play fighting games so much these days. I also didn't anticipate that I was going to play it with friends or even against others on the internet. So the appeal was potentially limited.

I wasn't convinced playing the tutorial - to be honest I was a little intimidated. While there are a lot of combat options to choose from, some of them were quite fiddly and would no doubt take a while to master. This is great if you want to play against others, but I only wanted to play the story. I wondered how far button mashing was going to take me.

I started playing through the story mode thinking that I would play a fight or two, and then stop, but I didn't.

Why?

Simply put, the story in I:GAU is fantastic. I don't think I have played a fighting game with such a solid story. Nor have I  played a game where the cuts scenes are so well integrated with the game. The writing is excellent. The voice talent - some of whom you will know from other DC games (or cartoons) is spot on. The same goes for the character's physical and facial expression. Whle the story isn't long, it's very satisfying.

in terms of gameplay, while button mashing got me a long way (I played on normal difficulty) it was very easy to pause and flick to a quick list of moves that I could try in combat. Fighting was fun! I enjoyed the variety of powers on offer, and I was pleased that the power discrepancy between characters is acknowledged and (kind of) addressed.

So. If you love DC, but are not sure about fighting games, give it a shot. If you love DC and love fighting games, it's a no brainer.

reviewText: I would want to like you Injustice, I really would, but every time I play you I get reminded of how much of a shoddy cash-in port you are. Your canned console graphics made me have to install SweetFX just so I could have the game not look worse than on my Xbox while having a 1920s film grain filter over it. That's what I get for simply trying to support fighting games on Steam.

reviewText: This was a pretty satisfying comic based fighting game. The graphics were slick, the levels well detailed and even interactive, and the fighter roster was brimming with most of my favorites. Add in a pretty competent fighting system and tons of unlockables for the characters and you got one of the better DC based games, forget the fact that it's a fighting game. The story came together incredibly well and felt like a complete 10-20 issue story arc. The best part was that it was structured in a way that you swapped out fighters to progress and this swapping played into the cohesiveness of the story, which is something seldom done well in a fighter. My only quibble is the terrific buildup of tension and amazing moments punctuated by a rather anti-climatic or boring conclusion. In this case the journey is far greater than the destination.

reviewText:
Injustice: Gods Among Us is a fighting game which uses various DC characters to tell an original story about a parallel world run by a broken, evil Superman and the Insurgent movements trying to overthrown is violent regime, with familiar superheroes and villains taking one side or another.
The main attraction of Injustice's battle systems is how the characters interact with the various levels: your attacks will damage the backrgound, you can actually use some elements from the scenary to your advantage and you can throw your opponent in a different part of the stage. It's very pleasant to watch and a vital part of gameplay. Beside that, Injustice is a pretty solid fighting game: each hero or villain has a wide moveset that defines his play style, unique lines, intros, outros and special, cinematic, devastating moves. The developers have used the DC license very well: the characters design is mostly faithful and fitting, the story makes full use of the heroes and villains various backstories and attitudes and they interact differently between themselves in battle. While the main plot of the game is nothing new in the DC universe, it mantains itself entertaining and interesting. It even throws some mini-games in from time to time to keep things interesting.
The title's controls are the only thing worth criticizing. The controller's movement patterns make pulling off certain moves far harder than it needs to be, and the keyboard mapping is just plain awful to play with.
Injustice spots both single and multiplayers modes. The former is about a story mode, a series of battle modes with unique challenges and a free battles mode; the latter is about competing with other players online or with a friend. The most peculiar mode in Injustice are the S.T.A.R. labs missions: a series of battles with special conditions making use of the different characters. There is also an unlock system to gain new skins for the fighters, concept art, music and more.
The Ultimate Edition only introduces the five DLC characters (Zatanna, General Zod, Batgirl, Lobo and Martian Manhunter) and unlocks all the costume packs released this far. Aside from that, there isn't any new feature to be found.
All things considered, Injustice: Gods Among Us is a very interesting game for a DC fan and a good fighting game to boot

reviewText: It's good. It's really good. Injustice is without doubt one of the best fighting games I have ever played, next to Mortal Kombat and Soul Calibour. What Injustice does well... is mostly everything. It has very good graphics, tight controls, many playable characters from whom every single is different, several arenas, most of which have two stages each, and I could not even tell if it was a console port. Most heroes have several different outfits, which is good in most cases, but looking at Teen Titans costumes for Raven and Cyborg I didn't find them similiar in any degree to their cartoon counterparts. And I kind of missed a Starfire character. On the other hand there is a version of Batman that wears a Russian ushanka, and there is Superman skin with a hammer'n'sickle emblem on his chest, and that is just plain awesome. Every character also has their own exclusive super move, or whatever it is called, which is a counterpart of the X-ray moves from Mortal Kombat. So in addition to pummeling the crap out of his foes, Batman can run someone over with the Batmobile, and Joker can blast someone with a bazooka, which I have no idea where he keeps.There are several game modes for singleplayer, which will keep you playing for a long time. There is story mode, classic battle and lots of its variations, and S.T.A.R. labs, which consists of lots and lots of minigames and small quests. Overall, this game has some minor flaws, like the completly redundant clash mechanic, or rare issues with attacks ghost range, but it is still solid and fun fighting game. But there is one thing that keeps it from ranking higher, at least in PC version, and it is the multiplayer mode. It sucks. It sucks so bad...I didn't even have a chance to play it. Seriously. You can wait for an hour and not find a single (!) match. And it is not even the game's fault. It is just that nobody plays it, which makes me sad. So, for the love of all gods, buy this game and play it, because for now, from my experience, about 20 people own it.\n\nInjustice: Gods Among Us gets my eight points out of ten.

reviewText:
This game is made by Netherrealm who make the Mortal Kombat games - a special character that you can play in the game is Scorpion.
Graphically it looks a lot like Mortal Kombat 9. The combat plays and feels like a Mortal Kombat game. Special Moves are also  executed in Mortal Kombat style.
But this game is not as bloody as Mortal Kombat => there is almost no blood. There are impressive moves that you can execute when a power meter is full - they are impressive but they're not as gruesome as fatalities.
There are destructible environments, things you can grab and launch at your enemies and in most of the arena's you can kick your enemies to another arena (=> this happens with an impressive cut scene that does damage to your enemy.


Characters:
I am not a comic fan so some of these characters are unknown to me. The Batman characters are fun though.

Game Modes:
I only played Single Player so I can't say anything on multiplayer.
There is a story mode which will take you of few hours to finish. I would recommend starting with that so you get familiar with some of the characters. I f you played the Mortal Kombat 9 story mode then you know what you can expect.

Next to that you have a lot of different single player modes that you can play and of course the traditional SP-mode 'arcade' like most other fighting games.

reviewText:
It's a great game, and it's a lot of fun, but the PC port is terribly handled. It always creates 60 frames, even if it can't display them all, so if you get, say, 40fps instead of the 60 it's doing, your game runs at 2/3rds speed. The game wants me to play on what's basically a Gamecube resolution to fix this problem. Not cool. Not cool at all.

EDIT: So, a LOT of my problems were because the game was trying to use my motherboard's graphics chip instead of my video card. Once I fixed that, I turned down the AA and shadows settings and it looks and runs great, but I still say you need to be wary of technical problems on this one. Any sort of slowdown makes it very hard to play.

The actual gameplay is great- very similiar to MK9, with simple to perform specials and a servicable combo system that I do wish was something more traditional. The biggest improvement is the Character Powers, which open up a lot of possibilities and really inform the character's playstyle by adding effects to attacks, acting as parries, etc. And once again, NRS made a great story mode. Really, the only issue I have are the technical aspects.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Despite it's flaws, Injustuce is a rock solid fighter, in single and multiplayer modes. I've played through the story mode and played a good amount vs on the XBOX so here's the difference to the pc version. In a nutshell, not a whole lot and that's not a bad thing. The controls are identicle, which is to say they're responsive and the moves are natural to execute for anyone that's played any Street Fighter/Mortal Kombat style fighter. The game play is fluid and effects such as AF and AA make a difference to the graphics but it's not enough to write home about.

This version includes the DLC characters like Zod and Zatanna and has kept all the original characters in the same state as when the game first launched. This is unfortunately the case for the broken (almost unstoppable) characters (see Deathstroke, Doomsday and Superman) are still broken and in dire need of a mild nerf or in the case of Deathstroke a complete overhaul, the stuff he pulls off even has a visual effect that suggests he's glitched.

The local multiplayer works well, but online is affected by heavy latency issues attributed to the lack of a local server in Australia.

This is one of the few fighting games that does the story so right that even the enjoyable fight sequences are pushed to the background, almost becomming a chore... almost. I wonder if the game might have pulled it off better if they didn't use the standard 2 round fight system and had the 1 round with longer health bars. That extra few seconds between the rounds just takes something away from the atmosphere. The one element to the story that irked me was Wonder Woman's depiction, despite her strength and nobility she was relegated to 'love interest' always needing to be saved/helped... Also what the hell were they thinking with Harley Quinn's street walker outfit? I like skin as much as the next guy, but damn that was over the top!

Anyway...

If you like superheroes this game is a must! If you like fighting games, it's still damned good, Injustice plays more like Mortal Kombat (naturally since it's the same studio as the prior release) than Street Fighter or King of Fighters, but it's not bound by the same rules and feel. There seems to be a large competetive scene but be warned again. if you're not in a region with a server you're not going to have the best experience.

My experience with with 'modern' superheroes was mostly limited to the 90's cartoons, in particular the 90's Batman, Spiderman and X-men cartoons and their successors, before that it was the usuall Transformers, Ninja Turtles, M.A.S.K, etc. Back then it was all about Marvel cartoons, with the exception of the afformentioned Batman, DC just felt tired and tried too hard. Fast forward to the present or a few years ago to my late 20's and I've found a whole new respect for the DC line of characters and stories. Thanks mostly to the more recent animated movies and catoon series' like The Justice League. WB seems to know how to put out good feature length animated movies over their big budget attempts, and the story arc's are more in line with what the fans know to be true to the comics. Whatever the case, Injustice: Gods Among Us does real justice to the DC universe.

reviewText:
As a former Mortal Kombat player back on the ole Playstation, I was really excited to play this game. In fact, the single player story line is actually pretty interesting if that's all you care about. Sadly, that's about the only thing that was good about this game.

The controls were terrible both with the keyboard & using controller support (Xbox 360). Sensitivity & response with the analog sticks on the controller were terrible. For example, your intention was to push the stick away to the left/right of your opponent, resulting in a block, but your character ends up jumping & gets pounded in mid-air. The D-pad was slightly better, but still terrible. Now for the keyboard. Some very effective melee combos are literally close to impossible to perform, as the game requires you to hit 4+ keys in a timely manner with your right hand, all while your left hand is pushing another 4 keys for movement. It feels like you're playing Twister with your fingers.

Pros:
- Solid single player campaign.
- Good graphics.
- Assortment of characters & costumes to choose from = excellent.
- Cool animations & combos when you can actually perform them.

Cons:
- Little to no control over character movement with controller support.
- Combo success rate almost nonexistent with keyboard.
- Multiplayer matchmaking nonexistent at times.

This is not a terrible game. Unfortunately, I personally don't think this game is worth recommending to others because of its poor character control/movement.

reviewText:
Online does not work.  Now that that's out of the way, this game is pretty fun against AI.  Pick it up when it's on a good sale.  But again, do not expect that you'll get to play it online.  If you've played or seen a Mortal Kombat game, you'll have an idea of what this is going to be.

The playable characters are: The Flash, Nightwing, Batman, Cyborg, Green Arrow, Superman, Raven <3, Aquaman, Wonder Woman, Hawkgirl <3, Shazam, Green Lantern, The Joker, Harley Quinn, Solomon Grundy, Lex Luthor, Catwoman, Deathstroke, Ares, Killer Frost, Doomsday, Sinestro, Black Adam, Bane, Martian Manhunter, Batgirl, Zatanna, Lobo, and Zod, along with Scorpion (the only character that is from Mortal Kombat and not DC).  All have their own unique moves, and most of them have different skins to use.

There are different kinds of singleplayer modes including a story, or you can simply do just individual 1v1 fights (which I prefer).

Overall it's a fun experience, however there are some issues I've had with the keyboard controls.  Sometimes things just don't seem to work.  Controller is better if you have one, unfortunately I do not.

reviewText:
This game broke the mold for fighting games with it's debut: Injustice - Gods Among Us is an adrenaline-fueled fighting game that is everything you'd expect from veteran game designers NetherRealm Studios.

They powerfully brought the DC Universe to life with a huge roster of Super Heroes and Super Villains to choose from, as well as a wide selection of stages to battle on - including specific parts of said stages.

Thought the fighting genre was getting stale?
Couldn't agree more - that's why NetherRealm brought new innovation to the table.

Now you can interact with your environments!
Fully destructable and fully interactive stages to battle on.
Swing from a chandelier to drop down on your opponent, grab a motorcycle to run them over with, throw them through walls to cause environmental damage and to send them soaring to another part of the stage. This game has it all.

Each character is usually assigned to a specific style of gameplay - some are gadget users and some use sheer strength.
Each has their own unique abilities as well as their own special move that does huge damage to your opponent.

This game is the epitome of superhero fighting games.

10/10

reviewText:
Really good fighting game for PC! if your looking for a competitive easy to pick up and play fighter for the PC, then this is the game for you. There's no real need to know anything about the characters just so long as you know there names and my knowledge of DC is pretty thin, but that didn't stop me from enjoying this game as I was mostly interested because of Batman as he's the only DC character I know well.

But this game truly makes you like all the characters each character has a different unique fighting style and powers, which make each fight different I found myself liking other characters apart from Bats although he's my favourite character to play normally, I grew to like Green Arrow, The Flash, and surprisingly Aquaman. But the most interesting character in this game is Superman we get to see him at his worst and at his best, this game shows how evil Superman can be and it's quite scary because of the things he does he clearly shows that he's not afraid to kill anyone.

The way the game does this is that there are alternate universers so the evil Supes is the result of what happened when The Joker destroyed Metropolis and tricked Superman into thining he himself did it, and so drives him down a dark path meanwhile the Batman from their universe brings over the original Good heroes from the other dimension and they team up to try and bring evil Supes down. It's a pretty good story and the cutscenes are enjoyable to watch with great visuals and even better voice acting it's hands down the best Super Hero fighter i've played.

I highly reccommend you get this game if you enjoy fighing games like Mortal Kombat which this game can be compared to but I prefer this over it, so whenever you get a chance grab it I guarantee you will have fun.

reviewText:
I'm not a strong fight game player but I enjoy them from time to time. Injustice is fun and visceral and plays pretty well on the PC, at least in terms of performance and responsiveness.

The story line is a hot mess as seems to be standard for comic books but it serves well enough as a framework for a number of entertaining fights. The ramping of difficutly seems very nicely tuned with the AI slowly ramping up the challenge as you hone your skills in the game. Outside the story line the game options are robust, far more here than a casual fight player such as myself can be a good judge of.

I can't say enough good things about the animation and character models. Its a damned pretty game with a wide range very interesting characters. The transition scenes you can trigger to go from one stage to another are pure delight and easily the viusal highlight of the game.

reviewText:
I'm not really a fan of versus fighting games but this was a fun trip down memory lane. It's nice that I can play it on my computer so I don't have to dust off and hook up my Sega Genesis to play it!

I think the only two differences between this version and the '90s cartridge are that you can choose between two difficulty settings (the original, Sunsoft-standard impossible difficulty, and beatable") and you have a few different costumes to choose from for the fighters so that's a nice touch to bring this nostalgic classic up to modern times.

Thanks to Acclaim and Sunsoft for re-releasing this old school gem!"

reviewText:
Personal rating: Very Good" = 4/5

PROS:
+ awesome story
+ many different battle modes
+ lots of unlockables
+ leveling system
+ cool soundtrack

CONS:
- poor balance between characters
- occasional frame dip
- Online Multiplayer has a small amount of people

Comment:
First thing that came to my mind was Casual Mortal Kombat. But I played further the game showed me that it is not just a clone of MK with DC characters. Actually
date: the game has similar patterns but branches out to something different. The story feels good and sits well with the Injustice story line of DC Comics. With the various battle modes available it gives for many hours of gaming. The combos and gameplay of most characters feel unique and interesting. However
recommended: this comes at a price to balance because some characters are simply better than others when it comes to fighting. Some other negatives are an occassonal frame dip caused by game coding. Online Multiplayer is not what it used to be when it comes to the amount of players so make sure to have some friends to play this with. But all that aside I went and rated this from Good to Very Good because it's DC ... because I am a big fan of comics. There is nothing like punching Superman with Batman ... or destroying Doomsday with Harley Quinn. This game is FUN and has a cool soundtrack
hoursPlayed: recommended!"

reviewText:
Jacko Rating
8/10

A great fighting game in the same style as the Street Fighter and Tekken franchises which I absolutely adore and have done for many years.
Relying on more timing and reaction time than long memory straining combos of the fighting games that are targeted at the asian market.  You do not need 100+ hours to be competitive online but the real beauty of this game is the very solid acrade mode and the super impressive story mode which is the best and most thought out since Mortal Kombat Komplete Edition.
Graphics are above average for fighting games and the combat and playability are both good in all modes.  With a good balance of AI difficulty that you can set and the numerous options, costumes etc make this great value if you buy on sale as I did.  Don't pay over 20$ for this and you will definately get value for your money.
If you liked SF or Tekken then trust me you will like this.
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Pretty well ported apart from the online multiplayer which has horrendous net-code. So much lag even with a good connection. This game has a steep learning curve unless you're used to Mortal Kombat style of fighting games (this is made by the same developer after all). Compared to Mortal Kombat, this blows it out of the water. Great game, though disappointingly some key DC characters are missing in favor of obscure characters that no one cares about. Still, it's the best fighting game that I've played in recent years, only getting beaten out by Marvel VS Capcom. This is the only fighting game on steam that I personally think is worth the money that they charge. I usually only play single player so it's ok for me, but if you want to play online, steer clear until they fix it, if they ever do. 8/10

reviewText:
Injustice is a game created by NetherRealm Studios (FYI the creators of the highly proclaimed Mortal Kombat)
So you would think this is a good fighting right ? And you're right, at it's core this is a magnificent game(A good roster,perfectly balanced)

Now let's talk about the singleplayer:
In the singleplayer the members of the justice league get teleported to an alternate dimension where superman went rogue and runs a dictatorship, you progress through the story by doing 1v1's with all the characters and doing some minigames along the way. Aside from the story you get the classic modes that yoou can expect in a fighting game(training, arcade battles,local 1v1's)

And now the multiplayer:
DON'T BUY THIS GAME
This is a fighting game, so you are going to want to show of your skills with your favorite character, right ?
HOWEVER NetherRealm doesn't give A ♥♥♥♥ about this PC-port (yes i have the 360 version) the game just doesn't work.
You can find people but you can't actually connect to their games. Now i managed to host a lobby with my friends but after a couple matches the game just glitches and everyone leaves the lobby.(And this didn't happen once)

CONCLUSION:
Don't buy this game. If the multiplayer worked then this would be a whole different game. But seeing how the modes what you are going to be playing most don't work this game isn't worth the money. Comparing this to the 360 version this is just an all-out SCAM !

reviewText: I've just finished the Story Mode of the game, and I can easily say that, this title has the best fable a fightning genre game can offer, of all time. It was like watching a Justice League movie, something you need to experience for urself. The combat mechanics are pretty fluid, nearly perfect, equal to Mortal Combat style, thanks to Ed Boon, who's the co-creator of that dynasty; both of these titles come from the same studio. Backgrounds musics were also awesome. Probably the only minus I can give to this game will be its online part. There'll be no problem with versus mode on the same computer/console when you're playing with your friend. But matchmaking with other people around the world will hurt your time and patience, I can guarentee that. You can also read about other gamers talking about the empty lobbies. Let's just hope that, Warner Bros will take care of this issue. My final review note for Injustice is 8,7.

Injustice: Gods Among Us is 3D fighting game by NetherRealm Studios featuring many popular DC characters
date: each with their own unique moveset and powers. The fighting system is a slightly altered and refined version of NetherRealm's very popular Mortal Kombat.\n\nThe story of Injustice takes place in an alternative version of the DC Universe where Superman has killed The Joker and now rules over One Earth with supreme authority. You play as several fighters ranging from Batman

reviewText:
This game is easily the best fighter game I have ever played. Like most, it has the combos, chain of moves, characters (each with different abilities) but it does all this plus more. It's not like mortal combat where you rip heads off and punch arms off, it is more calm than that, as it is DC, and is not killing, but KOing, like tekkan or street fighter.

It contains 'stage transitions' kicking or punching people through the side of a map, causing another DC hero/villain to beat them up, or punching/kicking them through a building of some sort to get to a new map, changing the scenery. This leads onto the objects in the background that can be used to your advantage. Such as swinging on chandelier to kick your opponent, or sending a robot to self-destruct under a player's feet. The players even have they're own strengths, such as superman and bane being able to rip off chandeliers from the ceiling and smashing them onto people, whilst others settle for swinging off the chandelier and kicking the opponent in the face. If your disappointed that your favourite DC character wasnt in this game, look closer. If your fav character isnt a playable character, they're most probably in the background, as a stage transition, or a 'usable object' or just a moving player in the background.

The story makes sense and is incredibly gripping. I was excited to play on throughout the entire story. Then you have the S.T.A.R lab missions and the battles to complete. I was amazed at how well they included objects, and how well they captured each arena. If you have ever played any batman games, it's good to see how similar they look in this game. e.g. Arkham Asylum. even Hugo Strange can be seen in Arkham Asylum arena observing your fight, unfortunatley you cant pick him up and slam him into the opponent, as much as we know everyone would love to.

Overall, this game is amazing form me i'd give it a 9.6/10 - 96/100

reviewText:
Not that bad. It doesn't stand a chance with other fighting games such as Mortal Kombat or Tekken but it's really good to finally have an amazing and creative DC video game that isn't a Batman: Arkham game. It lacks a few features but it makes up for it by having really good voice acting, stunning graphics (especially on my laptop), an exciting roster, over the top combos and supermoves and original story that we will remember. However, I do recommend not buying this game if you already have an XBoxx 360 or PS3 edition. If you do have this for your console, then you'll only see the unlockables unlocked and some DLC. Trust me, you'll save money. As for PC gamers, this is awesome. Thanks a lot Netherrealm for making it easy for us PC gamers.

Hope you update with this stuff, or at least make a sequel:
1. Mini-games like The Joker throwing cards at Nightwing or Green Lantern and Sinestro in a buildig battle should not only be in Story Mode
2. A longer story mode.... or at least DLC packs that extend the story
3. More characters like The Atom, Starfire, Man Thing, Ra's Al Ghul, Scarecrow
4. More skins (Black Adam and Sinestro only have 2 skins!)
5. Character Upgrades
6. Smoother Animations

reviewText:
If you like DC Comics and fighting games, this game is worth picking up. Comes with all DLC to date (and I'm pretty sure there isn't going to be anymore).
If you don't want to fight other people online, there is a full story mode to go through with a DC Comics quality story (which is to say, there is an alternate universe, so nothing really matters). There is also STAR Labs, which is similar to the challenge tower from Mortal Kombat (2011). However all the rewards that come from doing STAR Labs are automatically unlocked already in the Ultimate Edition, so there isn't a whole lot of point to play it, since it can become quite frustrating and doesn't really have much to do with the main fighting game.

The hype has died down for this game, but there are still people that play it both online and offline, but there seem to be issues with the online. The netcode is not good, by any means. It can be bearable, or it can be 5 seconds of input lag, followed by frame drops, followed by losing connection to your opponent. The game is no longer region locked, however playing against someone on the otherside of the world is not going to go very well.

The game has gone through some significant balance reworks, so a lot of characters are now viable, but the game is very zoner dominated, so if you prefer fighters that are all about getting in your opponents face, you should probably give Injustice a miss.

Overall, if you're already a fighting game enthusiast, you have no doubt played many games that are better than Injustice that you should stick to. But if you are new to fighting games, or just a DC fan, then Injustice is very worth picking up, combos are a lot easier to do than in other fighting games since they are less time restrictive. Blocking is simplified; hold back to standing block in one direction, hold down to crouching block in both directions. Forward and backward throws can be broken with the same button. All characters share some attack moves, such as uppercuts, sweeps and bounces. All characters have a character power, which is a gimmick that can be used to help you play that character better.

Injustice: Gods Among Us is 3D fighting game by NetherRealm Studios featuring many popular DC characters
date: each with their own unique moveset and powers. The fighting system is a slightly altered and refined version of NetherRealm's very popular Mortal Kombat.\n\nThe story of Injustice takes place in an alternative version of the DC Universe where Superman has killed The Joker and now rules over One Earth with supreme authority. You play as several fighters ranging from Batman
hoursPlayed: Deathstroke
voteText: and even Joker himself (albeit another version) along with many others as you go through the campaign. The narrative is very enjoyable and somewhat inspired by plots found in DC Animated Movies.\n\nStages in this game are interesting
helpfulPercent: containing many interactable objects for damaging and escaping

commentsCount: especially "Top Rung

reviewText: It's late to review the game as of now as it was released on November 13, 2013 - quite some time ago.\n\nAnyway, the game is awesome" in one word !  I am big fan of Tekken and Mortal Combat franchises and I love these games very much. But this game has taken the hand to hand combat genre to a different level. Since
date: the game is entirely based on the DC universe - it will appeal to people who love DC comics (any comics lovers
recommended: for that matter) as well as people like me who plays and enjoys hand to hand combat games.\n\nSo
hoursPlayed:
let me just carry on with the review in detailed segments.

1) Story:

This game has a variety of single player options. One of them is the "Story mode". As it is described in the game
voteText: Superman from another parallel dimension looses control of his emotion - as the Joker tricked him to kill Louis and their unborn child along with the destruction of the entire Metropolis. After that he "crosses the line" and kills joker. This alters his personality and thus forms a "Earth 1 Govt." and ushers his reign. Some of his fellow league members joins him as a ruler and most of the rest of the heroes who stood against him dies. The remaining heroes
helpfulPercent: who are not with this "evil" superman forms the resistance
votesHelpful:
led by none other than Batman. The story starts as this resistance leader asks for for help from the heroes of our world by snatching them from our dimension. What happens next ??... play the game !

2) Graphics :

This the next thing that you would feel - is awesome! The effects are stunning and the scripts are seamlessly integrated to the context of the screen. The model details are very very accurate. Since I am using a stone age 9500 GT my system could only manage a bearable FPS only at 640x480 (ridiculous
votesTotal:
I know) I can't elaborate the graphics too much here ; but if I crank up the settings (and sacrifice the FPS) just to get the feel of the graphics - they really looked great on my 22" HD monitor.

3) Gameplay:

The game play is a bit difficult in the keyboard as it ported straight out of the console platform to PC. But anyway - its not Call of Duty either and most of the hand to hand combat games are created keeping consoles in mind. But after you get used to the controls a bit you will find that its a hell of an enjoyment in playing the game. The ghosting effects are pretty less once you get the feel of your system's I/O lags- still its easy to carry on combos or streaks of attacks.

The environment is engaging and interactive to a large extent (considering the genre)- things that you can pick up and throw at your opponents. the maps(levels) may have multiple sections where you can hit the wall along with your opponent and smash it to transit to next area. And this entire functions can generate combo hits.

Overall the game is a "go" from my side
votesFunny: hope that it will do justice to you as well.\n\n- Justice -"

reviewText:
Pretty damn good.

Easy to learn, hard to master.  This is the game where Netherealm is really thinking about how to keep their fighting systems consisent with other accepted fighting game systems.  This is the game that will reconsile several fighting game styles into a cohesive system.  It's about time and very welcome to us PC players who are craving...no desperate...to see quality fighters come to our platform of choice.

We're entering an era where arcade fighters can really compare to PC versions, but I would say this is the first one to pull it off so well.  (my personal request is to see a revivial of the SNK/Playmore titles....oh god buy them if you can,)

Thanks guys, and please keep going.

reviewText:
Injustice is a great 2d fighter game. I've played it locally and online with friends.

Gameplay-
Injustice has great gameplay. You can pull off combos and use special moves. You can also interact with the map to hurt the other players. You can block, jump, hit, and more. Rating: 9/10

Graphics-
It is 2d, but the game looks amazing. There is detail in the background and characters. Rating: 8/10

Online-
The game has online but good luck finding a match. Currently, the online is empty and you should try to find people to play with. Rating: 4/10(no one plays online)

Price-
The game costs $20 as of 1/27/2016. It comes with all the dlc(yes including scorpion). I bought it when it was on sale for $5 and haven't regretted it since. The game goes on sale often so I would definitely pick it up when it's on sale. Rating: 7/10

Controls-
You can use a keyboard or a controller. You can use the keyboard to play it as well as a controller. It is very easy to map the buttons. Rating: 9/10

Story Mode-
The story mode was kind of short but I think the story itself is good. You play as many characters in the story and if you play the mobile too, you can get Prison Superman on the mobile edition by completing the story mode on PC or any other console. Rating: 8/10

Overall Rating: 8/10

reviewText: I really enjoyed this game. The fighting mechanics are well thought out. I love playing as batman or ARES. reviewText:
As a fighting game enthusiast, coming from the Street Fighter series, Super Smash Bros., and Soulcalibur to today's generation of fighting games (Street Fighter 4, MvC3, SFxT, etc) I have to say that this DC Super Hero version has met, and somewhat exceeded, certain expectations.

Now first off, I do have to say I didn't have great expectations to begin with, considering how the past generation of Mortal Combat games were a bit under par(in my opinion). But certain previews at least gave me some hope. I'm also not some elite player in all those games, but I can pull my own weight to at least offer some perspective about certain fighting games. And based on what I've played so far, I was actually impressed. I'll try to note some of the highlights that caught my attention. I've completed the single player campaign and played many hours of online vs mode. This review may assist with someone still on the fence about the game, and wanting certain answers.

[GAMEPLAY Highlights]

- Fight style is very similar to Mortal Kombat, as one would assume. However, there is no more need for a block button. This time, just hold back (away from opponent). This makes it easier for new players, unfamiliar to MK, to pick up. Basically, allows for a larger audience. However, hardcore MK fans may or may not appreciate this.

- There is a meter bar that is built up with attacks. Up to four meters to be used individually for move cancellations, or full meter for Super Signature moves.

- Ability to cancel certain abilities/combos (uses a meter bar), helps to connect long chained combos.

- Basic combos are simple enough for newbies to make use of. But, it can get complex enough to keep the hardcore entertained in finding long combo strings.

- Meter bar also used for wager mode. While you're being chain hit, you can cancel the opponent's chain by initiating a clash". During this phase you and the opponent place a "bet" of your meter. 1-4 of your meter to be used in the wager

reviewText:
Pretty damn good.

Easy to learn, hard to master.  This is the game where Netherealm is really thinking about how to keep their fighting systems consisent with other accepted fighting game systems.  This is the game that will reconsile several fighting game styles into a cohesive system.  It's about time and very welcome to us PC players who are craving...no desperate...to see quality fighters come to our platform of choice.

We're entering an era where arcade fighters can really compare to PC versions, but I would say this is the first one to pull it off so well.  (my personal request is to see a revivial of the SNK/Playmore titles....oh god buy them if you can,)

Thanks guys, and please keep going.

reviewText:
Injustice is a great 2d fighter game. I've played it locally and online with friends.

Gameplay-
Injustice has great gameplay. You can pull off combos and use special moves. You can also interact with the map to hurt the other players. You can block, jump, hit, and more. Rating: 9/10

Graphics-
It is 2d, but the game looks amazing. There is detail in the background and characters. Rating: 8/10

Online-
The game has online but good luck finding a match. Currently, the online is empty and you should try to find people to play with. Rating: 4/10(no one plays online)

Price-
The game costs $20 as of 1/27/2016. It comes with all the dlc(yes including scorpion). I bought it when it was on sale for $5 and haven't regretted it since. The game goes on sale often so I would definitely pick it up when it's on sale. Rating: 7/10

Controls-
You can use a keyboard or a controller. You can use the keyboard to play it as well as a controller. It is very easy to map the buttons. Rating: 9/10

Story Mode-
The story mode was kind of short but I think the story itself is good. You play as many characters in the story and if you play the mobile too, you can get Prison Superman on the mobile edition by completing the story mode on PC or any other console. Rating: 8/10

Overall Rating: 8/10

reviewText: It's late to review the game as of now as it was released on November 13, 2013 - quite some time ago.\n\nAnyway, the game is awesome" in one word !  I am big fan of Tekken and Mortal Combat franchises and I love these games very much. But this game has taken the hand to hand combat genre to a different level. Since
date: the game is entirely based on the DC universe - it will appeal to people who love DC comics (any comics lovers
recommended: for that matter) as well as people like me who plays and enjoys hand to hand combat games.\n\nSo
hoursPlayed:
let me just carry on with the review in detailed segments.

1) Story:

This game has a variety of single player options. One of them is the "Story mode". As it is described in the game
voteText: Superman from another parallel dimension looses control of his emotion - as the Joker tricked him to kill Louis and their unborn child along with the destruction of the entire Metropolis. After that he "crosses the line" and kills joker. This alters his personality and thus forms a "Earth 1 Govt." and ushers his reign. Some of his fellow league members joins him as a ruler and most of the rest of the heroes who stood against him dies. The remaining heroes
helpfulPercent: who are not with this "evil" superman forms the resistance
votesHelpful:
led by none other than Batman. The story starts as this resistance leader asks for for help from the heroes of our world by snatching them from our dimension. What happens next ??... play the game !

2) Graphics :

This the next thing that you would feel - is awesome! The effects are stunning and the scripts are seamlessly integrated to the context of the screen. The model details are very very accurate. Since I am using a stone age 9500 GT my system could only manage a bearable FPS only at 640x480 (ridiculous
votesTotal:
I know) I can't elaborate the graphics too much here ; but if I crank up the settings (and sacrifice the FPS) just to get the feel of the graphics - they really looked great on my 22" HD monitor.

3) Gameplay:

The game play is a bit difficult in the keyboard as it ported straight out of the console platform to PC. But anyway - its not Call of Duty either and most of the hand to hand combat games are created keeping consoles in mind. But after you get used to the controls a bit you will find that its a hell of an enjoyment in playing the game. The ghosting effects are pretty less once you get the feel of your system's I/O lags- still its easy to carry on combos or streaks of attacks.

The environment is engaging and interactive to a large extent (considering the genre)- things that you can pick up and throw at your opponents. the maps(levels) may have multiple sections where you can hit the wall along with your opponent and smash it to transit to next area. And this entire functions can generate combo hits.

Overall the game is a "go" from my side
votesFunny: hope that it will do justice to you as well.\n\n- Justice -"

reviewText:
Normally i am not quite a fighting game fan, but for this game i make an exception.

I have beaten the main campaign in the first 4.5 hours of play, which is most of what i want to do in a game. I can tell you that i'd have finished the campaign also when it'd have been much longer, the story is good. There are many playable characters and way more combo's and tricks than i can remember from the tutorial, the performance of the game is good. There's a good split between player interaction and cutscenes, though i must add that there are quicktime events.

Usually i'd start hating on any game with quicktime events. However, I:GAU has done it right. Failing quicktime events (partially at least) does give the player a disadvantage in the upfollowing battle, like having less starting health. Though it doesn't force you to redo any of it, unlike the dreadfull tombraider quicktime events.

All in all i don't really have anything to complain about with this game, note that I played with keyboard and not a controller and had a good time regardless.

reviewText: The controls are terrible and the combo timing is horribly unfriendly. How is it Capcom was able to make fighting games 20 years ago that were fluid and responsive and these yahoos still can't figure it out?\n\nI have been playing it on medium difficulty- Well, playing" is being generous. More like having my rear end handed to me in almost every match because the computer doesn't have to slog through terrible controls and can react faster than my character on screen can animate the move I told it to do. Hey developers- it's called a difficulty curve for a reason- the game starts off easier and gets progressively harder. Also
date: medium difficulty should mean that someone with experience in the genre can pick it up fairly quickly. Frustration is not fun- why is this such a difficult concept for game developers to grasp?\n\nThe graphics look beautiful- provided you have a very high end video card to run it. Anything less looks like crap. I don't know how

As a single player game, I guess it's fun.

I honestly can't recommend it for the full price of the game.  However, if you buy the game with the limited expectation of playing  only the single player mode (and the story's not that bad for a fighting game), it's worth a few bucks during a sale.

reviewText: Graphics and Connection...\nWhere to begin, I play this game on my PS4 and it's absolutly great, I've spent hours into button mashing and having competitions with friends so it was no suprise I'd buy this for PC. I bought this game for a friend and I and first launched it to find out the horrible graphic difference, the screen acted similar to a static TV making the game turn to pixels and jutter over and over again. At first I was fine with this, a little graphic difference wont hurt but then came the connection problems, It took forever to set up a game with my friend who i also bought the game for and once we got in the lobby every move made was extremely laggy running at 3 frames, this is a suprise since we both have good graphic cards and ram. It got to the point where during our games the lobby would crash repeatedly and kick us from the match as well as turning the screen to junky pixels. I'm very disapointed since this is a game I love to play on my other consoles and I've wasted my money unable to get a refund. Not Recommended if you intend to play on PC.
