reviewText:
If you, like me, have Windows 8, DO NOT buy this. It's horribly optimized and doesn't always even run. Sometimes, you have to restart Steam in order for it to work, which is ridiculous.

I managed to play about an hour of this until I got sick of how the game ran, it's crashes, it's compatibility issues, and horrible optimization.

In that hour, I must admit that the game was fun. It has plenty of characters that are all very interesting and familiar if you're a big fan of DC Comics. The environmnets are interesting, interactive, and dynamic to certain extents, which makes combat even more fun. I managed to play through Batman's chapter in the Story mode, which was entertaining and good. The story seemed interesting enough to play through, yet nothing amazing or far too great.

The fighting is cool and good since all characters have their own finishes, moves, and combat styles. It's well balanced between the characters and it feels like as if this could have been a competetive fighter even.

In the end, I recommend this to those of you who have Windows 7. To those of you who have Windows 8, or lower, DO NOT BUY. Actually, even if you do have Windows 7, I highly recommend you think about purchasing this. I'm glad I got this on a sale...

reviewText: Full controller support? I think not. Yes, the game has ported with pseudo-joystick support, and even has a convenient icon to remind idiots they are using a joystick. The problems begin with the fact that this game uses direct-controller mapping, meaning those of us who have invested in programmable pc peripherals, such as the aforementioned sticks or, say, expensive mice and keyboards are sol (excuse my french). Add to this the fact that your expensive flight stick gets direct-mapped to an axis range of less than 1mm -yes, 1 milimeter- in any direction with a deadzone of roughly 2 nanometers -yes, we're now talking the distance between diodes on your processor- and you see where the fun" really begins. Your alternatives are to buy an xbox 360 controller and hope for better luck or try to use keyboard controls that are by necessity difficult for anyone with less than thirty fingers
recommended: who are trying to get by with just five. By the way

1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3 1/2 teaspoons baking powder
1 teaspoon salt
1 tablespoon white sugar

1. In a large bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder, salt and sugar. Make a well in the center and pour in the milk, egg and melted butter; mix until smooth.

2. Heat a lightly oiled griddle or frying pan over medium high heat. Pour or scoop the batter onto the griddle, using approximately 1/4 cup for each pancake. Brown on both sides and serve hot.

reviewText:
The UI in these menus, for a keyboard user, are absolutely atrocious. There is absolutely no excuse for incompetence to this degree for a game as big as this one.

I changed my controls, but that only affects anything in matches. Don't like controlling your menus with WASD, G, and J? Too bad. Have fun, kid.

Also, the netplay outright did not work. I couldn't play my ROOMMATE. Like, the person sitting right next to me, on his own machine. There's absolutely no excuse for that, either! One might ask, Why not just play locally on the same machine?" Because of reasons.

this game is inexcusable/10"

reviewText: This a great fighting game for starters,considering how easy and accessible the game is compared to Skullgirls or Street fighter 4.The graphics are good,it runs a solid 60fps like most fighting games. Recognizable characters give this game a Super Smash Brother's feel to it.The game,however,is extremely unbalanced when it comes to online play,and the netcode is horrible unless you get perfect matching connection with your opponent,in which case it is good and very playable.About half of the cast is viable,and the other half is complete garbage.The tutorial is well made and the training mode has some neat features.\n\nIn other words,If you're looking for an easy fighter to get into pretty quickly with fun mechanics, give this a shot.

reviewText:

It takes itself way too seriously, though, and some of the character models, such as both universes' versions of Batman, are just awful.

reviewText:
If you have a computer that's even slightly above the recommended specifications for this game, do not buy this game. I purchased this game when I had a computer that met the recommended specs and it worked perfectly at max settings. A nice, smooth 60 FPS.

But then, I made a big mistake! I felt that Injustice, a game not even two years old, could handle a good computer! A computer with eight cores instead of four and a solid graphics card. What a fool I was! No, Injustice showed me the error of my ways. It was sure to not even utilize my GPU. It was sure to spike furiously between 27 and 50 FPS whenever I dared play a match.

Injustice looked at its two brothers, Mortal Kombat (2011) and Mortal Kombat X, and sneered in disgust. How DARE they function normally? How DARE they properly utilize the hardware of a computer? How DARE they work like games that were made in their respective years and not an alpha version of a 1991 MS-DOS script. Injustice would show them, Injustice would show them all!

The only real Injustice here is that I was screwed out of my money. I contacted WB Games and I was sure to get my buddy Marcus, who doesn't speak a lick of English but is fluent in copy-and-paste and corporate spittle. I stayed up all night and am writing this review while sleep-deprived and consumed by the fury of the gods. They don't care. As soon as they get their money, you mean nothing to them. I managed to rig my game to a somewhat working state through the equivalent of applying huge amounts of duct tape and WD-40 to it, yet the game still isn't entirely working right. I'll never get to play this game again and that saddens me.

reviewText:
I'm not sure where all the love for this game is coming from.  I played it for 30 minutes and decided to put it down.  This is the first time I've ever requested a refund for a game on Steam.  It's just not fun in any way.
If you have ever played a fighting game, then you've played this.  You're not going to find anything new here.

The controls just don't work.  15 of my 30 minutes were in the tutorial.  10 of those 15 minutes were spent on one move: Left, Right + X.  I don't know why, but it just doesn't work.  Must be a timing thing.  Do you have to hold down Left for a certain amount of time?  The game doesn't give you any hints.

Fighting games need to feel tight.  The hits need to feel like they're actually connecting.  The fighting in this game is clumsy and is very similar to those Street Fighter ripoff clones from the 90s.  The so-called combo attack system is very weak, when it actually works, which is rarely as the controls are pitiful.

The animation is awful.  Something is just wrong about Batman's face.  It's like his mouth is being sucked into a black hole hidden in his throat.  It's difficult to describe, but imagine what a lemon looks like if it were turned inside out.

Story is boring... The game just isn't good.  I'm a huge fan of the DC universe, but even my fanboyism couldn't make this game enjoyable.  I wish there was a demo so I could have avoided wasting Steam Support's time with my refund request.

reviewText: The mechanics serve well enough, obviously the same as Mortal Kombat, and the levels are interactive, which is interesting. There are also quite a few costumes, which would keep things from getting stale. However, even given all this, I ended up deleting the game files and requesting a refund 15 minutes into playing this. The female characters are all pretty dire, with most of the base costumes being pretty overly sexualized. Even when choosing those costumes which aren't just body-show (which one could claim is out of the hands of the developers as they were simply copying the costumes present in DCs often sexist comics), even the mesh animations (the way the characters move) and their attacks contort the players bodies to emphasize certain areas or are overtly sexual. On the subject of sexualization, I don't find sexual content in and of itself overly a problem in games, nor do I have a problem with the concept of porn, however, it always seems to end up targeting a certain demographic and marginalizing anyone not in that demographic. That is to say it's solely for straight (possibly white) guys, which basically limits who you can play this with.

reviewText:
I normally don't go in for PC fighters because my experience has only been of either fun titles with terrible performance or just plain terrible titles, but got this one on a whim as I couldn't resist the idea of some of the old favourite DC heroes and villains laying the smackdown on each other. So far, aside from a couple of gripes, I've been pretty happy with my spend.

I haven't yet played it to completion, but have been enjoying the playthrough so far. Visuals look beautiful on my rig even though it's getting pretty dated, and it runs quick and smooth without lagging or otherwise choking on those visuals without the need for turning any settings down, which is more than I can say for some of the other recent titles I've bought. The environments (and their interactions) look great but still don't draw attention away from the action when you're in the middle of it, and the cutscenes/cinematics I've seen so far don't summarily stop the action and butt in to the middle of a fight sequence right when you're on a roll.

The controls are crisp and responsive, but this is also where I feel more than a bit frustrated, as having no gamepad, I'm stuck using keyboard for the time being - the default controls aren't the most intutitive, and I've had some difficulties remapping them to what I'd like, which seems to possibly be due to the (admittedly cool) keyboard-based local multiplayer capability. That said, it's not an insurmountable, and I eventually figured out a layout that works well enough till I decide to spring for a controller.

8/10 so far - Good and fun, story where it counts, and a good way of tuning out for a bit at the end of the day.

reviewText:
The best fighting game I've ever played. Everything works exactly as it should. Controls are fully responsive, combos always work but can be changed up as desired, so lack of variety isn't an issue. This game has single-handedly turned me from hating fighting games to loving them, though after playing Injustice, I'm not entirely certain I want to play anything else the genre currently has to offer.

Pros:
- Awesome voice acting, especially the Clash quotes, which are fun, creative and varied
- Fun and creatively designed special moves, combos, and finishers
- Short but sweet story mode
- Solid tutorial
- Plenty of things to unlock even playing single player after beating the story mode
- Great animations, in terms of both speed and graphical feedback accuracy
- Fun terrain-based attacks, which add to variety and can be added into combos

Cons:
- No one is playing online on the PC version, so I assume it isn't cross-platform multiplayer, but honestly, I'm having fun just playing single player, as odd as that is for a fighting game, so this doesn't spoil the experience for me, and if I ever get a home console, I'll be grabbing this title first thing
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is fun for a while, but after about 50% of the single player missions, the fights against new charachters become a little to hard. Don't get me wrong, I like a challenge. But the single player missions force you to change character every 3 or 4 fights, so you cannot really get used to a single character and its moves. Also, almost every 5 or 6 fights, you get to fight against your own character. This is very confusing, because the visual differences between each character are minimal.
Later on in the single player missions, the fights get harder. You do minimal damage, while your enemy does a lot of damage, even with a single basic attack. When you lose, the difficulty is set back, which makes the same fight too easy. All these annoyances make that I cannot recommend this game.

So, in short:

Pros:
Great graphics
Nice physics
Finally a nice fighting game for PC

Cons:
Very long and boring cutscenes
Visual differences between same superheroes too minimal
Forced change of character in single player mission
Need to learn new moves each 3 or 4 fights
Difficulty-settings change dramatically when a fight is lost.
New missions are too hard when playing a new character and damage-balance is way off.

reviewText:
Oh my god, I think I just had a fangasm. I couldn't possibly comment further, on account of my bias.

Alright. 4 hours in, I think I've gotten the initial exhilaration out of the way. On initial first sight, it looks like nothing's been changed from the PS3 edition that I'd played six months ago, but a few comparisons here and there show that a little extra work on the textures here and there has been done, and it looks a lot slicker at being able to run at more than 30fps. All in all, while it takes a lot to get me into a fighting game (I also play streetfighter IV acrade edition when I'm being held at gunpoint), the combat mechanics ar simplistic enough for me to get to grips with, to the point that in combination with the characters on screen...I have an excellent time playing the game.

There's also a lot to keep teh comic book reader as well - the unlocks offer references to the comics, the skins look fantastic, and while some of the voice work is patchy at best, the fact that some effort has been put into at least TRYING to make them fit the character is gratifying in the least.

That said - despite all the DLC and the hope that more DLC will be released for the game, Injustice isn't a £40 (or $60) game. If you were willing to early adopt the game, it might have been worth that price, had it been released at the same time as the xbox 360 and ps3 version - the fact that people with both console and PC have a CLEAR advantage when it comes to knowing combos actually kind of diminishes it, and I feel the publishers missed a trick, as I would have loved to be in the crowd that inticipated which character would be released next.

All in all...If you see this game drop to £20 over the coming weeks, don't hesitate in buying it. the online co-op is fantasically smooth to the point that I doubt you'd have a problem matchmaking, and the storyline is absolutely brilliant - it's rare to have a game that has as strong a single player as it does a multiplayer.

reviewText:
(This review also comes from 30 hours game time on PS3)

If you're a fan of DC Comics and a fan of fighting games, this game is for you. If you have played MK-9 Before you will get used to this game fast enough. The graphics and the heroes are very good, you can hardly see any bad meshes in this game. The effects are outstanding and amazingly good.

Comparing this MK-9, you have the DC heroes, better graphics, better mechanics, more combos and more fighting variations, and the sounds are good. Plus, you can use your environment to change the arena in-game! And also use the environment to do harm to your enemy fighter in many ways.

If you're a fan of fighting games, you wouldn't care about multiplayer since we played all MKs on singleplayer before for the story and for arcade. Haven't tried online and not planning to anytime soon.

For the keyboard support there are two layouts. Both are great, and easy to learn.

Combos and special movements are now really easier than ever to learn thanks to the quick pause menu.

Finally, this game is absolutly worth it.

recommended: a lot of the characters only have 1 entrance animation and comment so it gets a little dull if playing multiple matches at once. Huge bonus to the PC version is fast loading times
hoursPlayed: where the consoles were awful. Absolutely recommend."

reviewText: Great game, though not a big fan of interactables. They do add a cool feeling to the fight and make it look cool, but I find that they become too much as you play. I found myself messing a combo up because an interactalbe would be there. Just kinda annoying but not to bad. Also like the Roster but I still feel like it's lacking, 22 Males and only 8 Females. We need more Female fighters and there are a bunch of good ones out there too. Finishing off the Teen Titans would be a smart choice and that adds Starfire and Donna Troy... and Tera. Black Canary... one of the best Fighters in DC, with a canary cry that would have cool combo flows. She was in a picture in the game, I think she should be on the roster. Poison Ivy would be a great addition, and Cheetah as well. So many more to increase the Female list. Huntress, Supergirl, Star Sapphire, Circe, Powergirl, Talia Al ghul. Maybe just as an add on since his armour was in the hall of justice map, add Doctor Fate. So Far though loving the Ultimate Edition and the skins. Hopefully we can get more out of this game in the New year, like skins for the DLC Characters and maybe even a addition to the story, that brings in the DLC Characters and possible additions.

reviewText:
This game is fun for a while, but after about 50% of the single player missions, the fights against new charachters become a little to hard. Don't get me wrong, I like a challenge. But the single player missions force you to change character every 3 or 4 fights, so you cannot really get used to a single character and its moves. Also, almost every 5 or 6 fights, you get to fight against your own character. This is very confusing, because the visual differences between each character are minimal.
Later on in the single player missions, the fights get harder. You do minimal damage, while your enemy does a lot of damage, even with a single basic attack. When you lose, the difficulty is set back, which makes the same fight too easy. All these annoyances make that I cannot recommend this game.

So, in short:

Pros:
Great graphics
Nice physics
Finally a nice fighting game for PC

Cons:
Very long and boring cutscenes
Visual differences between same superheroes too minimal
Forced change of character in single player mission
Need to learn new moves each 3 or 4 fights
Difficulty-settings change dramatically when a fight is lost.
New missions are too hard when playing a new character and damage-balance is way off.

reviewText: From the makers of Mortal Kombat (Netherrealm Studios) comes another rock solid fighting game that is hours of joy to play and master. Great game, great graphics and really cool roster of DC and one character from Mortal Kombat. All the DLCs are included in this edition. Plays a little like MK, but with a couple of differences. Your special attacks are identical to that of MK, but the blocking techniques are more like Street Fighter, so there will be a bit of a learning curve, if you're used to MK's style. Gameplay is also much faster to that of Mortal Kombat. And who can't enjoy seeing General Zod knocking The Joker through the moon?

reviewText: I am not much for fighting games usually, probably because I suck at them! But this game! It is worth it just for the single player story alone! I have been glued to my computer for the past 4 hours just watching this story unfold. A different and dark tale in the DC Universe. Never has Superman been so far off the rails! I plan on playing the game again just to watch the story again! As for the combat, even with my miserable skills and inability to hit the right buttons to make cool combos, I have still only had to repeat a handful of fights on the medium setting. So if you are not into fighting games, just pick this one up on sale and play on easy for the single player story. You will not regret it!

reviewText:
For a fighting game, this one surprised me by having a storyline that rivals most games. The main story involves Joker detonating a nuke in Gotham city and killing superman’s wife and unborn son. Superman goes crazy and the story goes on from there. The story will take players through other dimensions and into other characters. Starting off as Batman and going through the cast, Nightwing, Wonder Woman, Aquaman, etc...
Graphically this game will make you system shine if you've got the power to push it. The animations, and combos all look fantastic, and coming from a company that knows how fighting games are done, this one will not disappoint.
If you're a fan of the DC universe get this game, if your a fan of fighting games, get this game, or if you want something that looks great in Big Picture Mode, GET THIS GAME.

9/10

reviewText: Injustice: Gods Among Us, developed by Nether Realms (the same people who made MK9) game in my overall opinion is one of the good ones, a step up in 1v1 fighting games. The fighting mechanics are spot-on, it has an amazing story, and it takes place in the DC Universe! If you are a fan of DC or a fan of Mortal Kombat (I am a fan of both), get this game as soon as you get enough of your cash on your Steam Wallet! The Ultimate Edition is $10 cheaper and comes with ALL the DLC Content.

reviewText:
As weird as it may sounds to people, Injustice is my game of the year in 2013. I like fighting games (although being a noob at them) and I didn't expect much from it as I am not a big fan of Mortal Kombat or DC.

God was I in for a surprise.

It has some very fun unique concepts like how you can use the environnement against your opponement and the way it does it differs with every character (for instance, with a car, Batman will just jump off of it to go behind the opponement while Superman will hit you with the same car) The interactions also are stage-unique which makes stages more than comestic.

Ultimate moves can be pulled off easely even for beginners which is a nice touch for noobs like me. Zone transitions are very satisfying as well.

The story is very well written, it could easely be a movie and every fight has a purpose story-wise. Also, The Joker has some nice one-liners in it. I recommend doing it in one sitting which will last about 2 to 3 hours. You will still have character-unique endings by going through the arcade mode.

Overall, it is worth getting it even if you're not a DC fan and just looking for a fun fighter. It revolutionnes the way fighting games are made and I hope many other fighters like Street Fighter or King Of Fighters get some inspiration from some of the game's mechanics and the way the story mode is made.

reviewText: After a long wait for a PC port, finally got to play this game. As a DC Comics fan, this is just awesome and I never expected this to be so great. As a fighting game, it's pretty straight forward that any fan of the fighting game genre may feel at home here. However, for people like me who got used to Tekken, it took me a while to learn the moves, as the game has a very noob-unfriendly difficulty curve, where the level between easy & medium would just spike and the fights would be unforgiving if you don't know your moves. But once you learn the combos, the game would definitely be enjoyable and not as frustrating. Highly recommend!
